name: Henrietta Jones
biographical_notes: Henrietta Jones of Litchfield, Connecticut, was the daughter of Isaac and Tabitha Thomas Jones. Born December 14, 1805, Henrietta received her formal education at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy from 1821-1823. After completing her studies she served as an assistant teacher at the Litchfield Female Academy for five years. She was appointed Principal after Sarah Pierce retired and John Pierce Brace accepted the position as Principal of the Hartford Female Seminary. During her life Henrietta was also the head of academies in Rochester and Geneva, New York.
citation_of_attendance:
Transcribed notice written by the Trustees of the Litchfield Female Academy on October 30, 1833 to explain the changing of leadership of the Academy. Miss Pierce has retired, Mr. Brace has moved to Hartford so they name Henrietta Jones as the new Principal (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).
Letter, Sarah Pierce to John Pierce Brace, July 1833 (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).
1821 Litchfield Female Academy Catalog Summer Session (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).
1822 Litchfield Female Academy Catalogue published in The Litchfield Eagle on November 25, 1822 (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chroicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).
1823 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).
1823 Litchfield Female Academy Winter Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927). Henrietta wrote an inscription and signed her name in Martha Dwight Denison's album while a student at the Female Academy (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy Collection).
quotes: 'We are not without our trouble here the same spirit of fault finding as prevailed last winter has begun to show itself. Miss J is the sufferer, as she has the care of the older scholars, who are ambitious, & there is one who has risen by her superior mind far above her companions, & several have become jealous of her, & of Miss J, & accuse her of partiality. Miss Landon says there never was a more faithful & conscientious teacher, but she thinks the persecution she suffers will drive her back to Geneva, where they are constantly soliciting her return.' - Letter, Sarah Pierce to John Pierce Brace, July 1833 (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Mary E. Jones
biographical_notes: Mary E. Jones of New Haven, Connecticut attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1814. No other information is known about her identity at this time.

name: William Edwin Jones
biographical_notes: William Edwin Jones, son of Isaac and Tabitha Thomas Jones, was born in 1817. From 1829-1831 William studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in his hometown, as his sister Henrietta had done before him. While not much detail is known about Williams's life before his death in 1851, it is known that he married a Miss Ogden of New York City.

name: Amanda Keeler Rexford
biographical_notes: Born in 1804, Amanda Keeler Rexford was the daughter of businessman Jasper Sears Keeler of Albany, New York and his wife Mary. In 1816 Amanda received a formal education in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Four years later she married Gilbert F. Lush on January 5th. After Gilbert's death she remarried Lyman Spencer Rexford, a Yale graduate and minister.

name: Amelia Kellogg Stover
biographical_notes: Amelia Kellogg was the daughter of Aaron Kellogg and Amelia Noyes of Canaan, CT. Kellogg became a farmer in Canaan Center, NY, but left that area in 1832 for Binghamton, NY where he started a foundry business. After his business failed in 1837, Kellogg returned to Canaan, CT. Amelia married John Stover of Great Barrington, MA on September 2, 1824 and they had one child.
citation_of_attendance: 1820 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Maria Kellogg Grams
other_name: Maria Ann Kellogg; Maria Ann Mills
biographical_notes: Maria Kellogg Grams, daughter of Alexander Cyrus Kellogg and his wife Anna Sayles Kellogg, was born January 9, 1811. In 1824 she travelled from her hometown of Troy, New York to Litchfield, Connecticut where she studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy for two years. Maria married twice during her life. Her first marriage was to Charles Lewis Mills, a lawyer and businessman from Huntington, New York. During their marriage the couple had ten children. After Charles's death Maria wed Joshua Grams, a doctor from Corning, New York. On June 19m 1872 Maria passed away.

In 1825 Mary was sent by her parents to Litchfield, Connecticut where she studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. At some point after completing her studies Mary was wed to Horace Brewer.Little else is known about Mary's life except her death on June 25, 1884 at the age of sixty-five in Tecumseh, Michigan.

name: Laura Keyes Bronson
biographical_notes: Laura Keyes Bronson, daughter of Williams and Seba Smith Bronson of Batavia, New York, was born around the year 1793. In 1811 Laura may have travelled to Litchfield, Connecticut where she spent the year receiving an education at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. After completing her studies Laura wed Henry Ostrom Bronson, and the couple had six children during their marriage.
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]
additional_notes: Laura Keyes Bronson of Batavia, New York is listed as a subscriber to Sarah Pierce's text 'Universal History' in 1811. It is known that not all subscribers necessarily attended the school. Until a solid citation of attendance can be found Laura will be considered a possible student. -1811 List of Subscribers in Ist Vol. 'Universal History' (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. name: Eliza Kilbourn
biographical_notes: Eliza Kilbourn, daughter of Joseph and Hannah Sellew Kilbourn, was born on October 28, 1803. Registered as a student from Glastonbury, Connecticut Eliza attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1824 and 1825. Her brother Austin had been a Litchfield Law School student just a few years earlier. Little else is known about her life until her death on December 10, 1854.

name: James Kilbourn
other_education: He studied at Yale for two years as a non-graduate, and graduated from the Yale Divinity School in 1843.
biographical_notes: James Kilbourn, son of Whitman and Thalia Osborn Kilbourn, was born May 27, 1816. In 1831 James attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in his hometown of Litchfield, Connecticut. He later studied at Yale for two years as a non-graduate, and graduated from the Yale Divinity School in 1843. On December 12, 1838 he had married Amelia Kellogg Kilbourn. During their marriage James and Amelia resided in Bridewater and Middle Haddam, Connecticut and had four children.
citation_of_attendance: 1831 Litchfield Female Academy Winter Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Catherine King Pratt
biographical_notes: In 1810 Catherine King Pratt was born to Roswell and Katherine Barrington King of Darien, Georgia. In 1821 Catherine and her sister Eliza made the long journey from their home in Georgia to Litchfield, Connecticut where they spent the year studying at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. In March of 1830 Catherine married Rev. Nathaniel Alpheus Pratt of Saybrook, Connecticut. During their marriage the couple had ten children.
citation_of_attendance:
Catherine wrote an inscription and signed her name in Martha Dwight Denison's album while attending the Female Academy (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

other_education: Graduated from Yale in 1820 and received his Divinity Degree from Oglethorp University in 1854

name: Roswell King
biographical_notes: Roswell King, born May 3, 1765, was the son of Timonthy and Sarah Fitch King of Windsor, Connecticut. In 1782 Roswell enlisted in the Army at the age of 17. In 1789, after the end of the Revolutionary War he relocated to Darien, Georgia. In Georgia he became a successful businessman and not only ran a construciton business, but also became a landowner and was a commission broker for rice, cotton, and lumber. Roswell also served as Justice of the Peace. On April 14, 1792 he married Katherine Barrington King of Savilla Bluff, Georgia, and the couple began their family of ten children. From 1794 until 1795 he served in the Georgia House of Representatives. Owning plantations himself, he became the manager of Major Pierce Butler's plantations in 1802, but resigned by 1820. That year he became the director of the Bank of Darien. By 1830 he had begun developing land in northern Georgia, where he built dams and mills. In 1836 he founded the town of Roswell, and three years later set up the Roswell Manufacturing Company, which was the largest mill in northern Georgia. Roswell King continued to show an interest in the development of his land over the next handful of years, and on Febuary 15, 1844 he passed away while living with his widowed daughter Eliza King Hand.
government_posts: State/State House of Representatives//GA;Local/Justice of the Peace//Darien, GA

name: Eliza King Addis
biographical_notes: Eliza King Addis, registered as as a student from Litchfield, Connecticut, attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in 1832. While little is known about her life, it is known that Eliza married George Addis during her lifetime.

name: Eliza King Bayard
other_name: Eliza Barrington King; Eliza Barrington Hand
biographical_notes: Eliza King Bayard, born 1808, was the daughter of Roswell and Katherine Barrington King of Darien, Georgia. In 1821 Eliza traveled to Litchfield, Connecticut, where she was educated at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Three years later she wed Bayard E. Hand, a lawyer, and the couple had two children before his death in 1832. Eliza then married Nicholas James Bayard. Little else is known about Eliza's life until her death on January 13, 1883.
citation_of_attendance:
Eliza wrote an inscription and signed her name in Martha Dwight Denison's album while attending the Female Academy (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Bayard E. Hand
biographical_notes: Bayard E. Hand, son of Aarom and Tamar Platt Hand of Windsor, Connecticut, was born on December 10, 1800. During his adult life Bayard worked as a lawyer. On April 15, 1824 he was married to Eliza King of Darien, Georgia, and the couple had two children. Bayard's life was cut short however, when he died on October 27, 1832.

name: Nicholas James Bayard
biographical_notes: Nicholas James Bayard was born in 1779 in New York, New York. Little else is known about his life except his marriage to Eliza King Hand sometime after 1832.

name: Sarah Kingsbury Brown
biographical_notes: Sarah Kingsbury Brown, daughter of John and Marcia Bronson Kingsbury of Waterbury, Connecticut, was born on November 26, 1807. In 1823 Sarah attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. While studying in Litchfield Sarah boarded at Mrs. Bull's house on Prospect Street. Five years after completing her education in Litchfield Sarah marriaged Williams Brown. During their marriage Sarah and William had four children.

name: Phebe Kipp Best
biographical_notes: Phebe Kipp Best, daughter of Isacc and Hannah Mead Kipp of Hudson, New York, was born on January 1, 1800. In 1818, at the age of eighteen, Phebe traveled to Litchfield, Connecticut, where she studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Soon after completing her studies in Litchfield, she married Jeremiah J. Best of Claverack, New York. During their marriage Phebe and Jeremiah had five children. Little else is known about Phebe's life.

From 1816-1819 Katherine attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in her hometown of Litchfield, Connecticut. She later married Dr. Joseph Phycheon Russell on October 23, 1838, and resided in Governor's Island, New York. On January 6, 1882 at the age of eighty Katherine passed away.

biographical_notes: Harriot Kirby Belton, daughter of Ephrain and Ruth Marvin Kirby of Litchfield, Connecticut, was born on May 23, 1798. Prior to attending the Litchfield Female Academy, she attended the Rev. Claus Herrick's female school in New Haven, Connecticut in 1810. The following year she began studies at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy, and continued her education there for five years. On June 18, 1818 Harriot wed Francis S. Belton, and the couple had two children during their marriage.

name: Helen Kirby Putnam
biographical_notes: Helen Kirby Putnam, born November 18, 1800, was the daughter of Ephraim and Ruth Marvin Kirby of Litchfield, Connecticut. In 1814 and again from 1816-1819 Helen received a formal education in her hometown at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy, as many of her siblings did as well. Several years after completing her studies Helen married Benjamin Alexander Putnam in March of 1830. Benjamin, a lawyer and politician, was originally from Georgia and had travelled north in the early 1820s to attend Harvard. After their marriage Helen and Benjamin settled in St. Augustine, Florida. Helen passed away October 17, 1877.

biographical_notes: Esther Kissam McMurray, daughter of Peter Rutgers Kissam and his wife Deborah, was born around the year 1793. In 1806 Esther travelled from her hometown of New York, New York to Litchfield, Connecticut where she spent two years studying at the Litchfield Female Academy. Four years after completing her studies she married Rev. William McMurray of Salem, New York on November 19, 1811. The couple had eleven children during their marriage. In 1842 Esther passed away.

biographical_notes: Mary Landon Hallock was the granddaughter of Rev. Judah Champion, minister of the Litchfield Congregational Church during the Revolutionary War. She was born December 14, 1809 to John Russel Landon and his wife Anna of Castleton, Vermont. From 1816-1822 Mary studied in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. On August 25, 1840 she married Edward J. Hallcok, also of Castleton, Vermont, and the couple had one child. Mary passed away in 1861.

biographical_notes: In 1832 Mary Landon of Castleton, Vermont attended the Litchfield Female Academy. Mary was good friends with Betsey Wolcott, Elizabeth Cooke and Jane Lewis while studying in Litchfield. John Pierce Brace refered to these girls as 'The Club.'

name: Eliza Lanman Hubbard
biographical_notes: Eliza Lanman Hubbard, born April 20, 1800, was the daughter of James and Marian Chandler Lanman of Norwhich, Connecticut. In 1819 Eliza and her sister Sarah studied together at the Litchfield Female Academy. On October 30, 1821 Eliza married Amos Hallam Hubbard, a manufacturer, also from Norwhich. During their married Eliza and Amos had six children.

name: Sarah Lanman Harmar
biographical_notes: Sarah Lanman Harmar, born August 22, 1802, was the daughter of James and Marian Chandler Lanman of Norwich, Connecticut. In 1819 Sarah attended the Litchfield Female Academy with her sister Eliza. On October 5, 1830 she married Josiah Harmar of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Sarah and Josiah had three children.
citation_of_attendance: 1819 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Harriet Larned Kirby
room_and_board: Boarded at Parmalee's on South Street
biographical_notes: Harriet Larned Kirby, daughter of Simon and Ruth Ball Larned, was born September 13, 1796. It is believed that around 1809 Harriet travelled from her home in Maryland to Litchfield, Connecticut where she boarded at the Parmalee's house whilie attended the Litchfield Female Academy. Harriet later married Reynold Marvin Kirby, a former student at the Litchfield Law School.

name: Miss Larned
biographical_notes: In 1830 a student named Miss Larned attended the Litchfield Female Academy. While studying at Ms. Pierce's school she boarded at the Parmelee's house on South Street.
citation_of_attendance: A 'Miss Larned from Maryland' is mentioned in an interview given by Mrs. A.S. Farnam to Emily Noyes Vanderpoel (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Harriet Lathrop Winslow
biographical_notes: Harriet and James had six children. Harriet established the Batticotta Seminary in North Ceylon.

name: James Myron Winslow
other_education: Graduated from Middlebury College in 1815, received his Masters degree from Yale in 1818, earned a Doctor of Divinity degree from Harvard in 1838, and received his Doctor of Law from Middlebury in 1864

name: Lucy H. Lathrop
biographical_notes: In 1819 and 1820 Lucy H. Lathrop of Sherburn, New York attended the Litchfield Female Academy.
citation_of_attendance:
1819 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).
1820 Litchfield Female Academy Winter Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).
additional_notes: “Much ado about nothing.” An ecclaircisement has taken place relative to the “mysterious” lady who has excited so much interest on Oneida county. She is discovered to be a Miss Lathrop of Sherburne, who was educated at Litchfield in Connecticut; had returned a short time since to her friends, and had started, as was supposed, for Johnstown, where she represented she had taken a school. Among various visitors who were prompted by curiosity to see the mysterious stranger, was a young gentleman from Sherburne, who she immediately recognized and veiled her face. It excited suspicion, and on a closer examination he discovered who she was. She plead a derangement of her senses as an excuse for her conduct. It is supposed however that she got lost or bewildered going to the place where she was to take the stage, and patched up her story in order to avoid exposure and excite the sympathy of the people. She is now at Sherburne. - Oxford Gazette 12 September 1821, published in New York Spectator 21 September 1821 Vol. XXIV, p.2

In 1819 Ann and her sister Maria left their hometown of Sunbury, Georgia for Litchfield, Connecticut, where they attended the Litchfield Female Academy for two years. On February 16, 1828 Ann married William McQuir Maxwell. No other information is known about her life at this time.

biographical_notes: Maria Law Hugenin of Sunbury, Georgia was the daughter of Joseph Benjamin Law, Jr. and his wife Elizabeth. On March 12, 1828 she married a man named J.P. Hugenin. No other information is known about her life at this time.

Mary Ann later worked as a teacher in Westport, Connecticut, for forty-five years.

biographical_notes: Sally Leavenworth Smith, daughter of Gideon and Sarah Ward Leavenworth, was born on January 6, 1806 in Huntington, Connecticut. On January 6, 1806 she married James Smith, and the couple had two children.

name: Anne Leonard Holme
other_name: Anne Baldwin Leonard; Anne Baldwin Allen
biographical_notes: Anne Leonard Holme was one of several children to attende the Litchfield Female Academy. The daughter of Timothy and Mary Baldwin Leonard, Anne was born November 15, 1789. In 1804 Anne stuied at Sarah Pierce's Academy. During her lifetime Anne married twice. On October 14, 1817 she married Peleg Allen of Williamstown, Massachusetts. Peleg had graduated from Williams College in 1818, and worked as a doctor. During their marriage the couple had one child. After Peleg's death she married John Holme, originally from England, on October 21, 1831. Little else is known about her life.
citation_of_attendance: Anne completed a watercolor while attended the Litchfield Female Academy (Litchfield Historical Society).

name: Mary Leonard Marsh
biographical_notes: Mary Leonard Marsh, daughter of Timothy and Mary Baldwin Leonard of Lansingburg, New York, was born December 3, 1795. From 1813-1814 Mary and her sister Caroline received formal educations in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Two years later she married Charles Marsh, Jr. on November 27, 1816. Charles, a lawyer originally from Woodstock, Vermont, had been a law student in Litchfield in 1813. Their marriage was cut short however, when Charles passed away in July 1817. Mary's death soon followed in December of that year.
citation_of_attendance:
Mary is mentioned in a letter written by Julia Ann Crosby to Sarah and Hylah evier on October 22, 1813.
John Pierce Brace Journal, 1814 (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
additional_notes: Her maternal great grandfather was Reverend Timothy Collins, the first minister of the Congregational Church in Litchfield.

name: Jane Roxana Lewis
biographical_notes: Jane Roxana Lewis, born January 14, 1806, was the daughter of Luke and Mary Root Lewis of Litchfield, Connecticut. From 1819-1821 Jane received her formal education at Ms. Pierce's School in her hometown. While studying at the Female Academy Jane became good friends with Elizabeth (Betsey) Wolcott, Mary Landon and Elizabeth Cooke, and John Pierce Brace refered to these four girls as 'The Club.' Little else is known about Jane's life until her death in 1830.

name: Mary Ann Lewis
biographical_notes: In 1826 Mary Ann Lewis of New Haven, Connecticut attended the Litchfield Female Academy. No other information is known about her identity at this time.
citation_of_attendance: 1826 Litchfield Female Academy Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).
additional_notes: Mary Ann and sister Jane were invited to a Litchfield Law School ball managed by Samuel Glover, Jacob Delamotta, and Leroy Harvey, to be held at 'Mr. Deming's Assembly Room.'    Other invitations in the collection include Litchfield Law School students asking to escort Mary Ann to balls and cotillions.     Mary Ann Lewis Collection, Folder #5, ca. 1818-1823    Also see: Quincy Collection, Litchfield Historical Society, Collection of Litchfield Law School Ball Invitations
quotes: 'The pleasure of Miss Lewis' company is requested at a Ball to be given at the house of Mr. Phelps, on Tuesday, the 24th int. at 1/2 past 6 o'clock P.M.'    Hand-written invitation to Litchfield Law School ball, from George Boardman, George Devereaux, Joseph Clay Stiles, William Holt Averell, and William Greene, 1818    'Mr. Livingston regrets it is not in his power to accept Miss Lewis's polite invitation for this evening owing to a previous engagement.'    'Mr. Loring presents his compliments to the Misses Lewis' with his regrets that a previous engagement prevents his acceptance of the invitation to which they have favored him.'    'Mr. Reynolds and Mr. Adams return thanks to Misses Lewis for their politeness & will do themselves the pleasure to see them at tea this evening.' January 14, 1823    'I presume you have forgotten them -- I hope you will pardon this impoliteness.'    A note written by Fanny Lord and two other young women boarding at the Lord's home, accepting an invitation, but adding that Mary Ann had failed to invite law students Rutger Bleecker Miller and Henry Woodhull Greene, who also boarded at the Lord's.     Mary Ann Lewis Collection, Folder #5, ca. 1818-1823

citation_of_attendance: Nabby Lewis is mentioned in Charlotte Sheldon's 1796 diary that she kept while attending the Female Academy (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Sarah Azubah Lewis
biographical_notes: Sarah Azubah Lewis, daughter of Ezikeel and Martha Carrington Lewis, was born August 28, 1805. In 1820 she studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in her hometown of Litchfield, Connecticut.
citation_of_attendance: Emily Noyes Vanderpoel transcribed a letter written to her by Ann Eliza Jackson in 1897 recounting her memories of the Litchfield Female Academy (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: William Henry Lewis
biographical_notes: William Henry Lewis, born December 22, 1803, was the son of Ozias and Mary Jones Lewis of Litchfield, Connecticut. In 1820 and 1821 he attended the Litchfield Female Academy, as did several of his siblings.
citation_of_attendance:

name: Melissa Light Meyer
biographical_notes: In 1810 Melissa Light Meyer was born in Fishkill, New York to John and Elizabeth Graham Light. In 1826 Melissa was sent to Litchfield, Connecticut to be educated and spent the year studying at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Soon after completing her studies Melissa married John R. Meyer in 1829 and 1830. After their marriage the couple had two children. Melissa's life was cut short however when she passed away on February 19, 1831.
citation_of_attendance: 1826 Litchfield Female Academy Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Emily Lindsley Hollenbeck
room_and_board: Boarded with Lucy and David Parmelee
biographical_notes: Emily Lindsley Hollenbeck, daughter of Eleasur and Eunice Halsey Lindsley of Lindleytown, New York, was born May 3, 1796. From 1807-1811 Emily was educated in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. On September 23, 1816 she married George Matson Hollenbeck, a businessman and politician from Wilkesbarre, Pennsylvania. Emily passed away in September of 1851.
citation_of_attendance:
Miss Lindsley is mentioned in Sarah Beekman May 17 - August journal of 1807 (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
1811 receipt to Emily Lindsley for boarding and use of horse from David L. Parmelee (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

Letter, Emily Lindsley to Jerusha Lindsley, 4 December 1811 (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
secondary_sources: Lindly, John M. The History of the Lindley-Lindsley-Linsey Families in America. Winfield, IA.
additional_notes: Primary sources for Emily Lindsley Hollenbeck are located in the Litchfield Female Academy collection, Series 2: Student Papers, Records, and Documents, Folders 52-54.

name: Glorvina Lindsley Mines
biographical_notes: Glorvina Lindsley Mines was born in 1813 to Abraham Bradley Lindsley of Washington, D.C. and his wife Adelaide. In 1827 Glorvina travelled to Litchfield, Connecticut where she spent two years studying at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. On December 6, 1832 she married Rev. Flavel Scott Mines of Leesburg, Virginia. After their marriage the couple  had two children and resided in New Jersey, New York, and California. Glorivana passed away in 1838.

biographical_notes: Jerusha Lindsley Tharp, daughter of Eleasur and Eunice Lindsley of Lindsleytown, New York, was born January 19, 1793. The year after completing her studies she married Michael Rose Tharp on October 10, 1813. During their life together Jerusha and her husband had three children.

name: Harriot Loomis Clark
biographical_notes: Harriot Loomis Clark, daughter of Richard and Rachel Higbee Loomis of Torrington, Connecticut, may have studied at the Litchfield Female Academy in 1811. Five years later Harriot married Starr Clark of Utica, New York, and the couple relocated to Mexico, New York where Starr ran a local stove and tin shop. While residing in Mexico Harriot and her husband became active abolitionsits. The tin shop that Starr owned and operated served as a stop on the underground railroad, and in 1838 the couple actively participated in a vigilence committee to help escaped slaves to Canada.
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]

name: Abigail Lord Snelling
biographical_notes: Abigail Lord Snelling was born August 6, 1804 to Lynde Lord, Jr. and Mary Lyman Lord of Litchfield, Connecticut. From 1814-1819 and again in 1820 Abigial attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in her hometown. On April 15, 1824 she wed businessman Jonathan Snelling of Boston, Massachusetts. During their marriage the couple had three children. Abigail passed away in 1845.
citation_of_attendance:
A 'Miss Lord' is mentioned in Charlotte Smith's 1816 diary. This entry likely refers to Abigail Lord Sneling (Connecticut Historical Society).
'Catalogue of the Ladies Academy in Litchfield' 1818 by J.A. Shepard (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy Collection).
'Rules for the School and Family' and Names of the Young Ladies belonging to Miss Pierce's School in the Summer of 1814 (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy Collection).

secondary_sources: Woodruff, George C. A Genealogical Register of the Inhabitants of the Town of Litchfield, Conn. Hartford, CT: The Case, Lockwood and Brainard Company, 1900.
additional_notes: “Mrs. Mary Lyman Lord, from Northampton, was an accomplished and elegant woman. She did more toward promoting social life in Litchfield than any other one person. She was a finished singer and remarkable for her powers of concentration. Her first thought was for the happiness and comfort of those about her. She was beautiful in person and amiable in disposition, and was admired and loved beyond measure.” - 'Litchfield Celebrities,” Litchfield Sentinel, 1873 (Litchfield Historical Society, Scrapbooks).

name: Augustus Aurelian Lord
biographical_notes: Augustus Aurelian Lord, son of Erastus Aurelian Lord and his wife Charlotte, was born November 5, 1815. In 1829 Augustus studied at the Litchfield Female Academy, as his sister Corinna would also. Augustus later became a businessman, and was a merchant in Litchfield.
citation_of_attendance: 1829 Litchfield Female Academy Winter Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Erastus Aurelian Lord
biographical_notes:
Erastus Lord was born in Litchfield in 1792. He was trained as a bookbinder and began his career in Boston, Massachusetts. Unable to open his own shop, he worked out of the general goods story of family friend John Neal. When Neal and Lord’s brother in-law John Pierpont decided to open a store in Baltimore, Maryland, Lord followed.
He returned to Litchfield a few years later in 1822 and opened a “pocket book manufactury” on North Street where he advertised all type of leather covered goods including portfolios, pocket books or wallets, sewing cases and jewelry cases. He quickly expanded moving his shop into the town center on West Street and renaming his business Lord’s Book and Variety Shop. His stock increased in variety as Lord attempted to appeal to a broader audience of consumers.
The attempt to grow his business proved catastrophic for Lord. By 1838, he was over extended and his creditors were calling for payment. Lord was declared an insolvent debtor and forced to liquidate his assets.
Lord ended his career by worked for his son Augustus who continued his father’s leather goods business in Litchfield. Augustus was able to achieve the success that eluded his father. Under his ownership, the business flourished during the 1840s and Augustus sold wallets to dry goods merchants across the east coast.
materials: Mary Lord & Erastus A. Lord Bonds;Wallet - ca. between 1822 and 1838;Card Case;Mary Lord & Erastus Lord Bonds

name: Frances Lothrop Lathrop
biographical_notes: Frances Lothrop Lathrop was the daughter of John Hosmer Lothrop of Utica, New York and his wife Jerusha. In 1825 and 1826 Frances received a formal education in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. A handful of years later she married John Hiram Lathrop on March 15, 1833. John, a Yale and Hamilton College graduated, worked as an educator during their marriage, and the couple had seven children.

name: Abigail Lyman Greene
biographical_notes: Abigail Lyman Greene, daughter of Erastus and Abigail Bracket Lyman of Norwich, Massachusetts, was born September 19, 1801. In 1816 and 1817 she attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. After completing her studies in 1817 she married William Greene, a student at the Litchfield Law School. Abigail and William later lived in Ohio.

secondary_sources:
Lesley, Susan I. Recollections of My Mother. Boston: Press of Geo. H. Ellis, 1886.
Butterfield, L.H., et al., ed. The book of Abigail and John : selected letters of the Adams family, 1762-1784. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1975.
additional_notes: On July 13, 1820, William wrote to Abigail that Litchfield Law Student James Davis jilted Litchfield Female Academy student Amelia Peck from New Haven.    #168 GR Papers
quotes: 'Our coalition parties commenced last Friday week. They will be continued once a fortnight for three months. Their sociability contributes much to my enjoyment; and the exercise of dancing promotes my health.'    Written to Abigail by William Greene, December 29, 1818  Box I, #90 RG Coll Cincinnati Historical Society    'The Gentlemen will have a grand ball here on the 22nd in honour of Washington's birth.'    Written to Abigail by William Greene, February 16, 1819  Box I, #98    'My old friend Miss Flora C. has considerable talents -- but affectation spoils the whole. She is too aspiring in her disposition. She is constantly reaching after objects that are beyond the circle of her grasp; and imagining herself in a situation where her ambition would make her happy, she forgets her present standing and takes airs upon herself that render her ridiculous. She has an amazing longing after <U>marriage</U> and has not sufficient prudence to conceal her disposition in this particular. She has, notwithstanding all this, excellent qualities of heart and mind.'    Written to Abigail by William Greene, May 24, 1820 about about Litchfield bachelorette 'belle' Flora Catlin.  #161    '...poor Flora C. -- I am sure it would kill her to see Miss T [Tallmadge) married while <U>she</U> remained single.'    Written to Abigail by William Greene on December 11, 1820.    In 1820, Litchfeld Female Academy student Mary Ann Wolcott was romantically attached to Litchfield Law School student Henry Walter Livingston, whose family belonged to the old NY grant, Manor families (considered the closest thing to “aristocracy in the US”). Despite Mary Ann's own distinguished background ( it didn't meet the Livingston family's marital criteria and Henry ultimately ended the relationship. This caused a stir in the community and many students weighed in on the breakup via journal entries and letters.     Abigail wrote to William Greene:     “Since I wrote to you there have been several new engagements in this place. Mary Ann Wolcott is engaged to Mr. Henry Livingston a very elegant man in appearance with two hundred thousand dollars and Lord of the Manor. He is not overstocked with sense but sufficient to please her, what a satirical remark.”     William replied to Abigail on July 13, 1820 that the engagement only proved love was irrational and unpredictable. Evidently a long engagement was planned, which raised a red flag for William: “You ask me if I think Miss M ___ W’s ___ sentiments capable of constancy for two long years. I confess I should doubt it if there happened an occasion for her changing them. ...If they love each other sincerely now, they had better tie the knot as soon as possible.”

biographical_notes: Born on August 6, 1805, Cecelia Lyman Wiliston was the daughter of Asahel and Lucy Parsons Wiliston of Northampton, Massachusetts. In 1821 studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. She was wed to John Payson Wiliston six years later on March 6, 1827. Cecelia and John had nine children.

name: Lucretia Lyman Day
other_name: Lucretia C. Lyman; Lucy Starr Lyman; Lucy Starr Day
biographical_notes: Lucretia Lyman Day, daughter of Moses and Elizabeth Buell Lyman of Goshen, Connecticut, was born February 13, 1801. In 1821 Lucretia studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. After completing her studies in Litchfield she attended Emma Willard's Troy Female Seminary in Troy, New York the following year. On January 18, 1826 Lucretia married Caleb Day, a lawyer from Catskill, New York. During their marriage the couple resided in Catskill, and had five children.
citation_of_attendance: 1821 Litchfield Female Academy Catalog Summer Session (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Martha Lyman Sheldon
biographical_notes: Martha Lyman Sheldon of Norwich, Massachusetts was born in 1815 to lawyer Sylvester Lyman and his wife Elizabeth. As a young woman in 1829 Martha travelled to Litchfield, Connecticut where she studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. From 1835-1838 she taughter at Miss Martha (Margarette) Dwight's Gothic Seminary in Northampton, Massachusetts. On September 25, 1839 she was married to Rev. George Sheldon of Northampton. During their marriage the couple had six children.
citation_of_attendance: 1829 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: George Sheldon
other_education: Graduated from Williams College in 1835 and also received his Doctor of Divinity degree from Andover Theological Seminary

name: Mary Lyman Collins
biographical_notes: Mary Lyman Collins, daughter of Moses Lyman, Jr. of Goshen, Connecticut and his wife Ruth Collins Lyman, was born on June 27, 1787. Prior to 1811 Mary attended the Litchfield Female Academy, and on April 30, 1811 she wed Amos Morris Collins, a businessman and politician of Litchfield, Connecticut. Like her husband, Mary took her role in society very seriously, and was a founder and Secretary of the Hartford Maternal Association, taught bible class, did mission work in Hartford, worked in jails, visted insane retreats, helped with relief work during the Civil War, and was a founder and President of the Hartford Widows Society. During their marriage Mary and Amos resided in Blandford, Massachusetts and Hartford, Connecticut and had eight children. Mary passed way on may 8, 1879.
secondary_sources: Collins, Clarance Lyman. Collins Memorial. Private Printing, 1959.
benevolent_and_charitable_organizations: Hartford Maternal Association; Hartford Widows Society

name: Sarah Lyman Mead
biographical_notes: Sarah Lyman Mead of Goshen, Connecticut was born on April 18, 1805 to Samuel and Sarah Webster Lyman. In 1819 Sarah received her formal education in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. On May 15, 1827 she married Dr. Eslisha Mead of New York City.
citation_of_attendance: 1819 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

biographical_notes: Louisa Merrill Marsh, born May 16, 1810, was the daughter of Rev. Frederick Marsh of Winchester, Connecticut and his wife Parnall. name: Sarah Marsh Weston
biographical_notes: Sarah Marsh Weston of Dalton, Massachusetts was born August 2, 1799. Her parents were Henry and Betsey Lawrence Marsh. In 1816 Sarah studied at the Litchfield Female Academy. Four years later on November 2, 1820 she married businessman Grenville Dean Weston. The couple resided in Dalton and had three children. Sarah passed away in March of 1841.

name: Almira Marshall Clarke

On September 10, 1828 she wed Tertius S. Clarke a reverend from Deerfield, Massachusetts, and the couple went on to have four children. During their marriage Tertius's job moved the couple to many locations.

In 1816, and again from 1818-1819 Emma studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. On March 18, 1823 she married Samuel S. Fowler, and the couple had two children. Emma passed away in 1827.

name: Loiusa Marvin Swart
biographical_notes: Louisa Marvin Swart of Albany, New York was born November 7, 1802 to Uriah and Olive Ingrahm Marvin. From 1816-1817, and again in 1820 Louisa received a formal education in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Three year after completing her education she married Gilbert Devoe, and the couple had two children. After Gilbert's death Louisa was married to a gentleman named Mr. Swart.

name: Sarah May Wright
biographical_notes: Sarah May Wright, daughter of Caleb and Isabel Chandler May, was born April 13, 1800 in Woodstock, Connecticut. In 1820 she attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, and later married a man named Phineas Wright. The couple had at least one daughter during their marriage. Sarah passed away on May 26, 1875 and is burired in Putnam, Connecticut along with her husband.
citation_of_attendance: 1820 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

private_notes: A research contacted LHS in 2012 to let us know that their is additional information about Sarah Wright's family, especially her daughter, Betsey Wright Lee, in the book 'Remember Me: Women and Their Friendship Quilts' by Linda Otto Lipsett. LHS does not have a copy of this book, and it is not on google books.

biographical_notes: On October 8, 1801 Eliza Butler Maynard was born to Trowbridge and Rachel Harris Maynard of Rutland, Vermont. In 1820 Eliza attended Sarah Pierce's Feale Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. She passed away five years later.
citation_of_attendance: 1820 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Sarah McCurdy Mansfield
biographical_notes: Sarah McCurdy Mansfield may have attended the Litchfield Female Academy around the year 1803. Born November 17, 1788, she was the daughter of Lynde and Lydia Lockwood McCurdy of Norwich, Connecticut. On December 18, 1827 she married Elisha H. Mansfield, a businessman from Norwich. Four short years later Sarah passed away in 1831.
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]

name: Juliana McLachlan Gardiner
biographical_notes: Juliana McLachlan Gardiner, daughter of Michael McLachlan of New York, New York, was born February 8, 1799. From 1809-1813 Juliana attended the Litchfield Female Academy. In 1814 or 1815 she married David Gardiner, a lawyer and politician of Gardiner's Island, New York. The couple had four children during their marriage; one who married President Tyler.
citation_of_attendance:
List of students kept by Hylah Bevier in her 1811 edition of 'Universal History' (Locust Grove Estate).
John Pierce Brace Journal January 12, 1812 (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).
Letter, Julianna M. (McLauchlan) Gardiner to Jane P. Brace, 3 August 1813 (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
additional_notes: In 1819 when her father died Juliana, “came into possession of thirteen valuable pieces of commercial and residential property located in Chatham, Oliver, Greenwich, and Harrison streets. These produced at the time an annual rental income of $6000 to $7000, and during Juliana’s long tenure of ownership they steadily increased in marker value from $130,000 tp $182,000.” (Seager, Robert. And Tyler Too. McGraw-Hill: 1963).
quotes: 'Last night about eight, there was a message came to me to go down to the Farms for Cornelia [Van Kleek], Charlotte [Rose] and Juliana [McLachlan] who had staid there. Their horse had tired out, so that Nancy Starkweather, Mary Griswold and Mary Bulkley who would not stay, came up, partly on foot, and partly in the cutter leaving the other girls at a tavern under the protection of Alexander McLachlan (a little boy). Father would not let me go. Today I hear a vast many different stories that I do not know which I believe. Some say they wanted to stay & some say they did not. After meeting they came up.' - John Pierce Brace 1812 Journal (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Adaline McLean
biographical_notes: Adaline McLean of Utica, New York attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1818 and 1819. No other information is known about her identity at this time.

name: Miss McMechem
biographical_notes: In 1809 a Miss McMechem of Kinderhook, New York attended the Litchfield Female Academy. While studying at Ms. Pierce's school she boarded at the Baldwin house.
citation_of_attendance: She is mentioned in Catherine Van Schaack's Journal (New-York Histocial Society).
private_notes: This student may be either Mary McMechan or Matilda McMechan or Margaret McMechan, children of Margrieta can Vleck and Alexander McMechan.

name: Harriet McNeil Burchard
biographical_notes: Harriet McNeil Burchard, daughter of Henry and Margaret Simmons McNeil, was born in 1797 in Paris, New York. As a teenager Harriet attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut from 1814-1816. On April 4, 1821 she wed ely Burchard, a minister in Augusta, New York. After their marriage the couple resided in Augusta. In 1827 Ely began teaching at the Classical School in the village of Paris Hill, and he later served as the first teacher at a school in Sangerfield, New York. Ely and Harriet had four children, all of which were born in Paris, New York.
citation_of_attendance:
A 'Miss McNeil' is listed as a cast member in a handwritten copy of the play 'Two Cousins' by Sarah Pierce. This likely referes to Harriet McNeil Burchard (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
Eliza Ogden's 1816-1818 Diary (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 To 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).
'Rules for the School and Family' and Names of the Young Ladies belonging to Miss Pierce's School in the Summer of 1814 (Archives, Litchfield Historical Society).
1816 Litchfield Female Academy Catalog (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chroicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 To 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).
secondary_sources:
Dexter, Franklin Bowditch. Biographical Sketches of the Graduates of Yale College with Annals of College History, Vol. 6. New Haven: Yale University Press, 1912.
Jones, Pomroy. Annals and Recollections of Oneida County. Rome: Published by the Author, 1851.
quotes: 'In the afternoon Miss McNeal visited Miss Beecher and just at sun-down she invited me to take a walk with her and Miss Beecher on Prospect Hill; we had a very pleasnt walk indeed. When we arrived at the top of the hill Miss McNeal said that she always liked to look at that little cottage under the hill; it looked so rustic and retired, to which Miss Beecher replied taht she thought it was more pleasant to look at than to live in, a very true observation I think. After a stay of some minutes we concluded to go home. It was quite cool and we had no shawls with us.' - Eliza Ogden's 1816-1818 Diary (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 To 1833. Cambridge, MA: The Uiversity Press, 1903).

name: Ely Burchard
other_education: Attended Hamilton Oneida Academy, and graduated from Yale in 1811.

name: Louisa McNeil Camp
biographical_notes: Louisa McNeil Camp was the daughter of Samuel and Lavinia Johnson McNeil of Litchfield, Connecticut. Born on Jauary 4, 1812, Louisa received her formal education at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in her hometown in 1829. Six years after completing her studied she married Phineas W. Camp in 1835.
citation_of_attendance: 1829 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 To 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Polly McQueen
biographical_notes: Polly McQueen of Branford, Connecticut was born in 1778. It is believed that she may have attended the Litchfield Female Academy around 1800.
citation_of_attendance: Polly McQueen completed a mourning watercolor that is stylistically identical to mourning watercolors completed by Litchfield Female Academy students Ruth Pardee Upson and Elizabeth Catlin Cooke.

name: Ann Means Stuart
biographical_notes: The daughter of Robert and Mary Barnwell Means, Ann Means Stuart was born on May 12, 1808. In 1822 Ann traveled from her hometown of Beaufort, South Carolina to Litchfield, Connecticut to study at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Four years later she married Henry Middleton Stuart on May 11, 1826. The couple had ten children. Ann passed away on May 11, 1862.
citation_of_attendance: 1822 Litchfield Female Academy Catalogue published in The Litchfield Eagle on November 25, 1822 (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Isabella Means Desaussure
biographical_notes: Isabella Means Desaussure, daughter of Robert and Mary Barnwell Means of Beaufort, South Carolina, was born October 4, 1809. In 1822 Isabella travelled north to Litchfield, Connecticut where she spent the year studying at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. On November 15, 1832 she married Louis McPherson Desaussure. The couple had four children. Isabella passed away on January 16, 1844.
citation_of_attendance: 1822 Litchfield Female Academy Catalogue published in The Litchfield Eagle on November 25, 1822 (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Mary Means Fuller
biographical_notes: Mary Means Fuller, daughter of Robert and Mary Barnwell Means of Beaufort, South Carolina, was born January 1, 1811. In 1822 Robert and Mary sent Mary, along with her brother and two sisters, to Litchfield, Connecticut where they studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. On July 10, 1834 Mary married Henry Middleton Fuller. The couple resided in Beaufort during their marriage and had seven children. In October of 1878 Mary passed away.
citation_of_attendance: 1822 Litchfield Female Academy Catalogue published in The Litchfield Eagle on November 25, 1822 (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Thomas Means
biographical_notes: Thomas Means, born September 28, 1812, was the son of Robert and Mary Barnwell Means of Beaufort, South Carolina. In 1822 Thomas travelled to Litchfield, Connecticut where he studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy with his three sisters. Thomas later married Ann Hanckel Means on May 24, 1837, and the couple had one child.
citation_of_attendance: 1822 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Eliza Merkle Doughty
biographical_notes: Eliza Merkle Doughty, daughter of George Merkle of Poughkeepsie, New York, attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1814. Four years after completing her studies she married Isaac T. Doughty on August 23, 1818.
citation_of_attendance: 'Rules for the School and Family' and Names of the Young Ladies belonging to Miss Pierce's School in the Summer of 1814 (Archives, Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Mary Merriam
biographical_notes: Around the year 1825 a student named Mary Merriam is believed to have attended the Litchfield Female Academy. No other information is known about her at this time.
citation_of_attendance: 'Mary Merriam' was found written in lead pencil on the side of a dormer window in the Dr. Sheldon house along with a list of other students who presumably boarded at the house while attending the Litchfield Female Academy.

name: Caroline Merriman Stone Fusselman
other_name: Caroline Lucretia Merriman; Caroline Lucretia Stone
biographical_notes: Caroline Merriman Fusselman, born 1801, was the daughter of Dr. Titus Merriman of Bristol, Connecticut and his wife Polly Thompson Merriman. It is believed that Caroline may have attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy some time in between 1812 and 1814 in Litchfield, Connecticut. On September 16, 1822 Caroline married Roswell Stone, a politician from Bristol. After their marriage the couple relocated to Warren, Ohio, and had seven children. Nine years after Roswell's death in 1833 Caroline wed to John Fusselman of Ohio on December 6, 1842. She lived the rest of her life in Warren and passed away in 1878.
citation_of_attendance: The Rochester Museum and Science Center owns a memorial picture signed by Caroline N.T. Merriman which is stylistically similar to mourning watercolor's completed by documented students.
private_notes: The Rochester Historical Society has a memorial picture that may have been done by this student. Contact at the RHS is Sarah LeCount 585-271-4552 and email address sarah_lecount@rmsc.org.     The portrait of Caroline is owned by Judy Savage, and used with her permission. savahome@comcast.net.

name: Titus Merriman
biographical_notes: Moved to Bristol in 1792 and became one of the first members of the Hartford County Medical Society.

name: Polly Thompson Merriman
biographical_notes: Daughter of Isaiah Thompson.

name: Caroline Merwin Sanford
biographical_notes: Caroline Merwin Sanford of New Milford, Connecticut was born December 15, 1800. In 1816 Caroline's parents, Orange and Tryphena Warner Merwin, had Caroline educated at the Litchfield Female Academy. Several years later she married lawyer and politician David Curtis Sanford on September 1, 1822. Caroline passed away two years later on January 20, 1824.
citation_of_attendance: 1816 Litchfield Female Academy Catalog (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).
secondary_sources: Sanford, Carlton E. Thomas Sanford, Emigrant to New England. Higginson Book Company, 1991.

name: Harriet Merwin
biographical_notes: Harriet Merwin, daughter of Orange and Tryphena Warner Merwin of New Milford, Connecticut, was born March 12, 1811. In 1826 she attended the Litchfield Female Academy, as her two sisters had before her. Little else is known about Harriet's life until her deaht in 1867.
citation_of_attendance: 1826 Litchfield Female Academy Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Mary Minerva Merwin
biographical_notes: Mary Minerva Merwin was born May 11, 1811 to Noble Hawley Merwin of Cleveland, Ohio and his wife Minerva. From 1825-1827 Mary studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. She passed away in 1828.
citation_of_attendance:

name: Tryphenia Merwin Platt
biographical_notes: Tryphenia Merwin Platt, born May 4, 1806, was the daughter of Orange and Tryphena Warner Merwin of New Milford, Connecticut. In 1823 Tryphenia received a formal education in Litchfield at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy, as her sister Caroline had done before her. Two years after completing her studies in Litchfield Tryphenia married Marshall Smith Platt, and the couple went on to have eight children during their marriage. On June 2, 1870, at the age of 64 Tryphenia passed away.
citation_of_attendance: 1823 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Julia Metcalf
biographical_notes: Julia Metcalf of Dedham, Massachusetts was the daughter of Theron Metcalf and his wife Julia Tracy Metcalf. Theron, a lawyer, had studied law in Litchfield and his wife had been a Female Academy student. Following in her parent's footsteps Julia attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1827.

name: Henrietta Miles Brown
biographical_notes: Henrietta Miles Brown, daughter of John and Sarah Bills Miles of New Haven, Connecticut, was born in the year 1802. In 1814 Henrietta and her sister Elizabeth traveled to Litchfield, Connecticut where they spent the year being education at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. After completing her education Henrietta was married to Jacob Brown. Little else is known about her life.
citation_of_attendance: 'Rules for the School and Family' and Names of the Young Ladies belonging to Miss Pierce's School in the Summer of 1814 (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Elizabeth Mary Miles
biographical_notes: Elizabeth Mary Miles, born in the year 1800, was the daughter of John and Sarah Bills Miles of New Haven, Connecticut. In 1814 Elizabeth, along with her sister Henrietta, received a formal education in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy.
citation_of_attendance: 'Rules for the School and Family' and Names of the Young Ladies belonging to Miss Pierce's School in the Summer of 1814 (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Sally Miller
biographical_notes: Sally Miller, born around 1782, was the daughter of Stephem Miller, Jr. of Middletown, Connecticut and his wife Lucy. In 1811 Sally studied in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. No other details are known about her life at this time.
citation_of_attendance: Sally completed a mourning pictures while attending the Litchfield Female Academy (Metropolitan Museum of Art).

name: Almira Mills
biographical_notes: In 1820 a student named Almira Mills attended the Litchfield Female Academy. No further information is known about her identity at this time.

name: Amanda Mills Perry
other_name: Amanda L. Mills; Amanda L. Adams
biographical_notes: On November 5, 1800 Amanda Mills Perry was born to Lewis Bradley Mills of Kent, Connecticut and his wife Hannah. In 1821 Amanda travelled to Litchfield, Connecticut where she briefly studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. That same year she married Reuben Adams on March 1. After Reuben's death she married Nathaniel P. Perry on September 10, 1840. No other information is known about Amanda's life until her death on February 1, 1890.
citation_of_attendance: 1821 Litchfield Female Academy Catalog Winter Session (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Pamela E. Miner
biographical_notes: On June 3, 1791 Pamela E. Miner was born to John and Hannah Strong Miner. It is believed that because her older brother Phineas studied at the Litchfield Law School, Pamela may have also studied in Litchfield at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy.

name: Zerviah Ruth Miner
biographical_notes: Zerviah Ruth Miner of Litchfield, Connecticut was born March 18, 1811 to Phineas and Zerviah Butler Miner. From 1823-1827 her father, being a graduate of the Litchfield Law School, had Zerviah educated at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. No further information is known about Zerviah's life until her death in 1839.

name: Abigail Mitchell Brinsmade
biographical_notes: Abigail Mitchell Brinsmade, daughter of Simeon and Esther Farrand Mitchell of Washington, Connecticut, was born July 11, 1796. In 1818 Abigial traveled to nearby Litchfield, Connecticut where she spent the year studying at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. The following year, on Setpember 9, 1819 she wed Daniel Elliot Brinsmade, also of Washington. After their marriage the couple resided in their hometown, and had two children during their marriage. Abigail passed away in Washington April 26, 1835.
citation_of_attendance: 'Catalogue of the Ladies Academy in Litchfield' 1818 by J.A. Shepard (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Adeline Mitchell Tallmadge
other_name: Adaline H. Mitchell; Adaline Mitchell Tallmadge
biographical_notes: Adeline Mitchell Tallmadge of Plymouth, Connecticut was born January 1, 1804. In 1819 Adeline's parents, Thomas and Harriet Mitchell, sent her to Litchfield, Connecticut where she began two years of study at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Three years after completing her formal education she married Edwin Tallmadge on November 12, 1823.

name: Jane Mitchell Palmer
biographical_notes: Jane Mitchell Palmer was born in 1810 to Thomas and Harriet Thompson Mitchell of Plymouth, Connecticut. In 1824 she studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy, as her sister Adaline had. A few years after completing her formal education she married George Palmer, Jr. on September 12, 1827. No other information is known about her life at this time.
citation_of_attendance: 1824 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Margaret Mix Wood
biographical_notes: Margaret Mix Wood, daughter of Elihu and Nancy Atwater Mix, was born April 14, 1805 in New Haven, Connecticut. In 1818, 1819, and 1820 Margaret was educated in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. On September 5, 1825 she was wed to Dr. John William Wood of Stamford, Connecticut. The couple had five children during their marriage. Margaret passed away August 3, 1880.
citation_of_attendance:
'Catalogue of the Ladies Academy in Litchfield' 1818 by J.A. Shepard (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy Collection).
1819 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

John Pierce Brace, History of My Poetry, Vol. II (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).
quotes: “M. Mix’s farewell was written by request and copied by her. She had been some time with us and boarded at my father’s with me nad Lucy. She was from New Haven. An amiable and excellent girl. I believe her mother removed to the West – I have never heard what became of her. Margaret M Mixs farewell to Litchfield Oct. 1820 Litchfield farewell! No more thy street In broad expanse my eyes shall meet No more thy hills of cheerful green Or neat built houses shall be seen Or sky of ever living blue Or lakes that vie with it in hue. No more be seen those friends that twine Their merits round this heart of mine. Farewell that friend that nearest seen Who shares both waking hours and dreams Whose unsophisticated mind With strongest powers the heart can bind. Maria too in whom we find That innate dignity of mind That mark her form with all that grace That worth and innocence can trace. And Cooke whose emblem is the stream Whose surface shows no brightening gleam But still whose …. [torn page] Calmly and sweetly far below – Mary with feeling quick and bright As flashes of the Northern Light: Whose artless innocence endears. More than the worth of riper years, And Jane whose prompt and active mind By talents vigerous shoots entwined. Shows promise of the fairest flowers And richest fruits in future hours. And Wolcott o’er whose beaming face Good nature sheds her sweetest grace. Whose smile is like the glowing west. When every cloud has sought its rest. When balmy eve its softening blue Has Mix’d with tints of amber hue Where none can look and calm depart Nor feel the flow upon his heart – Friends of my heart tho’ doubly near Yet other friends are still as dear And those now claiming warmer love Which you and Litchfield ne’er can move.” John Pierce Brace, History of My Poetry, Vol. II (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927)

name: Julia Moffat Bowman
biographical_notes: Julia Moffat Bowman, daughter of Samuel and Bethia Reeder Bowman of Blooming Grove, New York, was born on May 20, 1806. In 1819 she traveled to Litchfield, Connecticut, where she spent the year studying at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. On december 14, 1826 Julia married Chancellor Livingston Bowman, a farmer. During their marriage, Julia and Chancellor resided in Blooming Grove, and the couple had five children.
citation_of_attendance: 1819 Litchfield Female Academy Winter Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 To 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Susan T. Moffat
biographical_notes: Susan T. Moffat of Blooming Grove, New York was the daughter of Nathaniel and Elizabeth Tuthill Moffat. In 1829 Susan travelled to Litchfield, Connecticut where she studied for a short time at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Nothing more is known about Susan's life until her death on February 4, 1875.
citation_of_attendance: 1819 Litchfield Female Academy Winter Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Daniel Green Whitney
biographical_notes: Daniel Green Whitney came to Quincy, Illinois from Marietta, Ohio. He possessed mercantile enterprise and skill, and carried on several branches of business in the Quincy area. He had a store on the west side of the square in Quincy, a distillery, a grist mill in the southern part of Adams county, and a warehouse on the Mississippi River. He built a home, known as 'Boscobel' and later owned by General James W. Singleton, east of the city. On August 13, 1838 Mr. Whitney was married to Mary Ann Monson Cutler, the widow of George Younglove Cutler of Hancock County. She passed away in 1844. In the late 1840's Mr. Whitney's business ventures in Illinois began to fail, and in 1849 he removed to California where he undertook new business ventures. In January of 1870 he died in a railroad car collision.

name: Sarah Moody Douglass
biographical_notes: From 1826-1827 Sarah Moody Douglass of Woodbury, Connecticut attended the Litchfield Female Academy. Born on August 10, 1811, she was the daughter of Ashbel and Sarah Marks Douglass. On November 19, 1834 Sarah was married to Levi Seabury Douglass of Cheshire, Connecticut. Nothing more is known about her life at this time.

name: Lucretia Moore Hubbell
other_name: Lucretia Matilda Moore; Lucretia Matilda Brinkerhoff
biographical_notes: Lucretia Moore Hubbell, daughter of Pliny and Martha Corbin Moore, was born in the year 1802. In 1819 Lucretia travelled from her hometown of Champlain, New York to Litchfield, Connecticut where she attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy for two years. While a studying in Litchfield Lucretia boarded at the Beecher home, and became a close personal friend of Catherine Beecher. In 1824 she married Abraham Devick Brinkerhoff, a minister from Fishkill, New York. After the death of her first husband she married Loring C. Hubbell, a lawyer and former sweetheart of Lucretia's. In 1852 she formed the first female benevolent group in her husband's parish in Chazy, New York. The group, lead by Lucretia, raised $513.83 to buy a parsonage for her family.
citation_of_attendance:
1819 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).
1820 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

secondary_sources:
Tuttle, Mrs. George Fuller, ed. Three Centuries in Champlain Valley. Plattsburgh, NY: Saranac Chapter D.A.R., 1909.
Sullivan, Nell Jane B. and David Kendall Martin. A History of the Town of Chazy, Clinton County, New York. Clinton, NY: Private Printing, 1970.
additional_notes: Lucretia Matilda Moore “… had been engaged to Loring G. Hubbell, a brother of Julius Caesar Hubbell, but he went away to war; and when he returned, she was already married to Brinkerhoff. Young Hubbell married a Spanish woman, who died after bearing him two children. When he returned to Chazy, a widower, he found Lucretia a widow, and the former sweethearts were finally married.”

name: Caroline Morgan
biographical_notes: Caroline Morgan, daughter of Dr. Dwell Morgan of Hartford, Connecticut and his wife Elizabeth, was born August 5, 1802. As a girl Caroline attended Lydia Huntley Sigourney's school in Hartford, Connecticut. She then began studying at the Litchfield Female Academy in 1818, and in 1819 she was joined by her sister Julia at Sarah Pierce's school. No other details are known about Caroline's life until her death in 1849.

name: Julia Morgan Brown
biographical_notes: Julia Morgan Brown was the daughter of Dwell and Elizabeth Smith Morgan of Hartford, Connecticut. Born on February 5, 1806, Julia attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut in 1819. On November 17, 1825 she married Benjamin H. Brown.

biographical_notes: On August 2, 1783 Abby Morris was born to James and Elizabeth Hubbard Morris. It is believed that around the year 1798 Abby may have attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in her hometown of Litchfield, Connecticut. Her brother James attended the Litchfield Law School a few years later in 1803.

name: Eliza Morrison Jackson
biographical_notes: Eliza Morrison Jackson, born April 26, 1813, was the daughter of James and Elizabeth Johnston Morrison of Savannah, Georgia. Because her father had attended the Litchfield Law School, and her mother the Litchfield Female Academy, it is believed that around the year 1830 Eliza may have studied in Litchfield as well. On May 20, 1835 she married John James Jackson, a businessman from Savannah. During their marriage Eliza and John had five children. She passed away in 1876.

name: Lydia Morrison Stewart
biographical_notes: Lydia Morrison Stewart of Montgomery, New York was born in 1808. She was the daughter of Hamilton Moore Morrison and his wife Lydia Beamer. In 1819 Lydia and her sister Prudence attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. She later married William Stewart In 1829.

name: Prudence Morrison Rapalje
biographical_notes: On November 1, 1801 Prudence Morrison Rapalje was born to Hamilton Moore Morrison and his wife Lydia. In 1819 Prudence and her sister Lydia travelled from her hometown of Montgomery, New York to Litchfield, Connecticut where they studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. The following year she married Stephen Rapalje. During their marriage Stephen was active in the underground railroad  in Montgomery.

name: Esther Hart Morse
biographical_notes: Esther Hart Morse, daughter of Alvin and Esther Johnson Morse, was born October 24, 1813. Around 1828 Esther is believed to have attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in her hometown of Litchfield, Connecticut.
citation_of_attendance: Esther completed a needlework at the age of fifteen. It is believed that this piece was done while attending the Litchfield Female Academy (Item in private collection).
private_notes: Malcolm Bramley bought her sampler from EBAY    “ESTHER HART MORSE SAMPLER WROUGHT IN THE 15 YEAR OF HER AGE”    House at bottom, fence, trees birds, “Early now in my youthful bloom Strive to walk in wisdoms ways”

name: Phoebe Moseley Bogardus
other_name: Phoebe Ann Ogden Moseley; Phebe Moseley
biographical_notes: Pheobe Moseley Bogardus, daughter of Jonathan Ogden Moseley and his wife Gertrude of East Haddam, Connecticut, was born June 27, 1785. It is believed that around the year 1800 Pheobe studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. In the early nineteenth century Phoebe was sent to boarding school in New York City, where she met her future husband Jacob I. Bogardus. After their marriage on August 7, 1808 the couple relocated to Pennsylvania, and they had ten children during their marriage.

Dakin of Oneida, New York, and the couple had five children. Mary passed away on February 20, 1863.

biographical_notes: Elizabeth Mygatt Hyde may have attended the Litchfield Female Academy in the year 1812. Born on June 2, 1799 she was the daughter of Noadiah and Clarissa Lines Mygatt of New Milford, Connecticut. During her lifetime Elizabeth married Austin Hyde, whom she had four chlidren with, and resided in Oxford, New York.

name: Henrietta Mygatt Butler
biographical_notes: Little is known about the life of Henrietta Mygatt Butler. Born in New Milford, Connecticut to Ezra and Sarah Nicholson Mygatt, Henrietta attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut in 1818. Eight years later she wed William Butler of Hartford, Connecticut.

name: Amanda Nash
biographical_notes: On November 3, 1785 Amanda Nash was born to Daniel and Abigail Dewey Nash of Great Barrington, Massachusetts,. It is believed that in 1803 Amanda may have attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy while her brother Lonson studied at the Litchfield Law School. She later married Rev. Sylvester Burt and they had one daughter.

Willard, and the couple had four children during their marriage.

name: Caroline Newcomb Cheesmen
biographical_notes: Caroline Newcomb Cheesmen, daughter of John and Ruth Bloom Newcomb of Pleasant Valley, New York, was born October 29, 1799. As a girl Caroline traveled to Litchfield, Connecticut in 1814, and received an education at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. She later married Filkins Cheesmen, a farmer from Clinton, New York, and the couple went on to have four children during their marriage. On November 10, 1850 Caroline passed away.
citation_of_attendance: 'Rules of the School and Family' and Names of the Young Ladies belonging to Miss Pierce's School in the Summer of 1814 (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Charlotte Newcomb Benedict
biographical_notes: Charlotte Newcomb Benedict, daughter of Thomas and Rachel Hopper Benedict of Pleasant Valley, New York, was born July 20, 1795. In 1809 she traveled to Litchfield, Connecticut where she studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Seven years later she wed Abijab G. Benedict, a doctor, of Salem, New York. The couple later moved to Red Hook, New York where Charlotte's husband continued his medical practice, and began a political career as well.
citation_of_attendance: Charlotte Newcomb Journal kept a journal while attending the Litchfield Female Academy (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
additional_notes: Primary sources for Charlotte Newcomb Benedict include a journal circa 1810, located in the Litchfield Female Academy collection, Series 2: Student Papers, Records, and Documents, Folder 10.
private_notes:
There is a second silk embroidery by Charlotte Hopper Newcomb still held in the family. As of 2000 it was owned by Carolyn S. Dole of Palo Alto, CA. She is the sister in-law of Steve Rogers who the museum purchased 'Moses in the Bullrushes' from at this time. Jessica Jenkins contacted Mrs. Dole via letter in May 2014.
The Springfield Museum of Art in Springfield, OH has Ammi Philips portraits of Charlotte Newcomb Benedict and Abijah G. Benedict in their collection. The portraits are dated 1822.
materials: Charlotte Newcomb Benedict Journal;Litchfield Female Academy Collection;Discovery of Moses in the Bullrushes by Charlotte Newcomb Benedict

name: Abijah G. Benedict
biographical_notes: Abijah G. Benedict obtained a medical license in 1815 from the Dutchess County Medical Society. Dr. James Down of Pleasant Valley served as his preceptor, and Benedict continued to work with him for the next three years. He then removed to Red Hook where he remained for the rest of his life. He was twice elected to the state legislature. From Transactions of the New York State Medial Society

biographical_notes: Amanda Nye of Amenia, New York was born in 1795 to Silvenus Nye and his wife Silvenia. In 1816 Amanda recieved her formal education in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. She later resided in North Carolina, Georgia, and New York.
citation_of_attendance: 1816 Litchfield Female Academy Catalog (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA; The University Press, 1903).

It is believed that Susan may have recieved a formal education at the Litchfield Female Academy like her sister Amanda. During her lifetime her married a man named Adam Hutchison, and work as an educator. She resided in Raleigh, North Carolina and Atlanta, Georgia.

name: Velina Oakley Wilkinson
biographical_notes: Velina Oakley Wilkinson of Poughkeepsie, New York was born in 1799 to Jesse and Jerusha Peters Oakley. In 1807 it is known that Velina traveled to Litchfield, Connecticut where she received a formal education at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Sometime after completing her studies Velina married a man named Gilbert Wilkinson.
citation_of_attendance: Miss Oakley is mentioned in Sarah Beekman's May 17 - August journal of 1807 (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy Collection).

name: Julia Oaks
biographical_notes: Julia Oaks of New Haven, Connecticut attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1828. No other information is known about her identity at this time.
