name: Amelia C. Ogden
biographical_notes: Amelia Ogden was the illegitimate daughter of Aaron Ogden. She was given her father's name and a financial legacy and then sent to live with relatives. In 1798, Amelia came to live with Sally Burr Reeve who was her cousin. It is believed that she attended the Litchfield Female Academy while a resident of Litchfield, and she eventually taught French at the school. During her time as a student Amelia was courted by several of the law students but never married. She remained at the Reeve house after the death of Sally and Tapping Reeve and acted as a companion to Judge Reeve's second wife. At her death, Amelia inherited the Reeve house where she lived until her own death in 1866. She was finanicially supported by her Devereux nephews, who attended the Law School and lived in South Carolina, until the Civil War when correspondence between the north and south stopped.
citation_of_attendance: She is listed as the French teacher on the 1830 Catalogue of the Litchfield Female Academy (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).
secondary_sources: 'Aaron Burr, ' Evening Post (ca. 1874) photocopy (Litchfield Historical Society - Reeve Collection).

name: Eliza Ogden Butler
biographical_notes: Eliza Ogden Butler, daughter of Abraham and Abigail Weed Ogden of Walton, New York, was born June 29, 1803. From 1816-1818 Eliza received her education in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. In October of 1825 Eliza married Charles Butler, a lawyer from New York, and the couple went on to have five children. They first resided in Geneva, NY until their removal to New York city in 1934 where Eliza led an active life in society and was the founder of the New York City Protestant Half Orphan Asylum. Her husband Charles was the founder of the Union Theological Seminary and gave $100,000 to New York University.
citation_of_attendance:
'Catalogue of the Ladies Academy in Litchfield' 1818 by J.A. Shepard (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
A 'Miss Ogden' is mentioned in Myra Coleman's 1818 diary. This entry likely refers to Eliza Ogden Butler (Connecticut Historical Society - Litchfield area family papers, 1794-1860).
Eliza Ogden kept a journal while attending the Litchfield Female Academy (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 To 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

additional_notes: Primary sources for Eliza Ogden Butler are located in the Litchfield Female Academy collection, Series 2: Student Papers, Records, and Documents, Folders 18-23.
benevolent_and_charitable_organizations: New York City Protestant Half Orphan Asylum
materials: Litchfield Female Academy Collection;Chart of the History of the Kings of England by Eliza Ogden Butler;Charles Butler Papers;Papers of Charles Butler

name: Caroline J. Orton
biographical_notes: From 1819-1820 Caroline J. Orton attended the Litchfield Female Academy. She was the daughter of James and Electa Graves Orton of Winfield, New York. James Orton attended Dartmouth College, graduating in 1787. He married his wife Electra in Pittsfield, Massachusetts in 1792. He was appointed judge to the county courts. For a time he lived in Litchfield, New York, which had been settled by a number of residents of Litchfield, Connecticut. Her younger sister Jane attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1822. Both sisters died within a month and half of one another.    No other information is known about Caroline at this time.
citation_of_attendance:
1819 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: James Orton
biographical_notes: James Orton was the son of Thomas Orton (disputed in his parents divorce) and Ann Dix.  After his parents divorce and his father's death, he was raised by his step-mother, Sarah Atwood, and her second husband, Col. Giles Jackson of Woodbury, CT.  He attended Dartmouth College, graduating in 1787. He married his wife Electra Graves, daughter of Moses Graves, in Pittsfield, Massachusetts in 1792. He was appointed judge to the county courts. For a time he lived in Litchfield, New York, which had been settled by a number of residents of Litchfield, Connecticut. Two of his daughters attended the Litchfield Female Academy and both died within a month and half of one another.

name: Electa Graves Orton
biographical_notes: Electra Graves was the daughter of Moses Graves.  She married James Orton in Pittsfield, Massachusetts in 1792. Her husband was appointed judge to the county courts. For a time they lived in Litchfield, New York, which had been settled by a number of residents of Litchfield, Connecticut. Two of her daughters attended the Litchfield Female Academy and both died within a month and half of one another.

name: Cynthia Painter Collins
biographical_notes: Born on August 20, 1791 to Thomas and Hannah Candee Painter of New Haven, Connecticut, Cynthia Painter Collins is believed to have possibly attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1806 and 1807. On May 15, 1815 she married Simeon Collins, and the couple went on to have six children. Cynthia passed away on April 28, 1880.
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]
additional_notes: Primary sources for Cynthia Painter Collins include a photograph of her on her 86th birthday and a photograph of an embroidery done while enrolled at the LFA. These are located in the Litchfield Female Academy collection, Series 2: Student Papers, Records, and Documents, Folder 36.
materials: Litchfield Female Academy Collection;Cynthia Collins photos

name: Laura Pardee Inslee
biographical_notes: Laura Pardee Inslee, daughter of Orrin and Julia Gay Pardee of Sharon, Connecticut, was born May 6, 1813. In 1830 Laura studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy as her mother had done. On November 14, 1837 she married Charles B. Inslee of Waterloo, New York. Little else is known about Laura's life until her death in 1896.
citation_of_attendance:
Laura wrote an inscription and signed her name in Jane Wadhams's autograph album while attending the Litchfield Female Academy (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
'Catalogue of the Litchfield Academy … 1830' (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Minerva Pardee Hubbell
biographical_notes: Minerva Pardee Hubbell, daughter of Rev. Amos Pardee and his wife Eunice, was born in 1797. In 1814 she travelled from her hometown of Lanesborough, Massachusetts to Litchfield, Connecticut where she spent the year studying at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Sometime after completing her studied she married Stoddard Hubbell, also of Lanesborough.
citation_of_attendance: 'Rules of the School and Family' and Names of the Young Ladies belonging to Miss Pierce's School in the Summer of 1814 (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Sarah Pardee Paine
biographical_notes: Sarah Pardee Paine was born on March 20, 1801 to Jonathan and Zilphea Hamlin Pardee of Sharon, Connecticut. In 1826 Sarah attended the Litchfield Female Academy, where she sister Rebecca may have studied several years earlier. Soon after completing her studies Sarah married Henry O. Hollister on September 5, 1827. After Henry's death she married Marvin P. Paine.
citation_of_attendance: 1826 Litchfield Female Academy Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

biographical_notes: From 1831-1832 Elizabeth Parker of Litchfield, Connecticut attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. No other information is known about her identity at this time.

name: Elizabeth Parks Bostwick
biographical_notes: Elizabeth Parks Bostwick, daughter of Josiah and Eliza Pierce Parks of Litchfield, Connecticut, was born July 23, 1818. From 1830 until 1832 Elizabeth studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in her hometown. On March 9, 1843 she married George Henry Bostwick of New Milford, Connecticut. Little else is known about Elizabeth's life.
citation_of_attendance: 'Catalogue of the Litchfield Academy … 1830' (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Mary Parks Wessells
biographical_notes: Mary Parks Wessells, daughter of Josiah and Eliza Paine Parks, was born February 5, 1820. It is believed that around 1832 Mary may have studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in her hometown, as her sister Elizabeth had. On December 14, 1840 Mary wed Leveritt Ward Wessells of Litchfield. The couple had seven children.
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]

name: Albert Ozias Parmalee
biographical_notes: Albert Ozias Parmalee, born December 9, 1806, was the son of David and Lucy Lewis Parmalee of Litchfield, Connecticut. In 1823 Albert, along with his siter Celeste, attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in his hometown.
citation_of_attendance: 1823 Litchfield Female Academy Winter Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Julia Parmelee
biographical_notes: In 1813 a student named Julia Parmalee attended the Litchfield Female Academy. No other information is known about her life at this time.
citation_of_attendance:
Julila wrote an inscription and signed her name in Elizabeth Catlin's 1813-1815 memory book (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
Emily Noyes Vanderpoel transcribed of copy of 'Jephthah's Daughter' a play written by Sarah Pierce for Chronicles of A Pioneer School. The students who acted in the play are listed - J.Parmalee played Mahalah (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Eliza Parsons Wadsworth
biographical_notes: Eliza Parsons Wadsworth of Canaan, Connecticut was born November 29, 1793. In 1819 she received her formal education at the Litchfield Female Academy. Her first husband, Phineas Miner, had also studied in Litchfield at the Law School. After Phineas's death Eliza was wed to Tertius Wadsworth.
citation_of_attendance: 1819 Litchfield Female Academy Winter Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).
quotes: '...she married a man by the name of Minor, whose first name I have forgotten. He only lived a few years after their marriage, and afterwards she married Tertius Wadsworth, of Hartford, who by a former marriage was the father of quite a large family of Wadsworths... I often heard my great aunt tell the story about riding from Litchfield to Hartford in an open sleigh in mid-winter, keeping as warm as toast.' - Letter, John Farwell (Litchfield Historical Society - Samuel Fisher Collection).

name: Miss Parsons
biographical_notes: In 1821 a Miss parsons of Granville, Massachusetts attended the Litchfield Female Academy. No other information is known about her identity at this time.
citation_of_attendance: 1821 Litchfield Female Academy Catalog Summer Session (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Almira Jane Partridge
biographical_notes: Almira Jane Partridge, born in 1809, was the daughter of Cyrus and Mary Loveland Partridge. In 1825 Almira travelled from her hometown of Norwich, Vermont to Litchfield, Connecticut where she studied for a short time at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Almira later lived in Wheatland, California. She passed away on January 1, 1865.
citation_of_attendance: 1825 Litchfield Female Academy Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Caroline Partridge Fessenden
biographical_notes: Caroline Partridge Fessenden of Sag Harbor, New York was born February 12, 1796. In 1811 she may have attended the Litchfield Female Academy. Seven years after completing her studies she married Thomas Fessenden, Esq. on October 8, 1818. During their marriage Caroline and Thomas had eight children. She passed away on December 10, 1873.
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]
additional_notes: Caroline Partridge Fessenden of Sag harbor, New York is listed as a subscriber to Sarah Pierce's text 'Universal History' in 1811. It is known that not all subscribers necessarily attended the school. Until a solid citation of attendance can be found Caroline will be considered a possible student. -1811 List of Subscribers in Ist Vol. 'Universal History' (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 To 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Hepzibah Partridge Billings
other_name: Hepzibah Dickinson Partridge; Hepsey Dickinson Partridge; Hepsey Dickinson Billings
biographical_notes: Hepzibah Partridge Billings, daughter of Samuel and Mabel Dickinson Partridge of Hatfield, Massachusetts, was born in 1797. In 1811 Hepzibah made the trip to Litchifeld, Connecticut, and spent time studying at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Five years later, on January 4, 1816 Hepziah was married to Israel Williams Billings. During their marriage they may have had one son, but sources are not consistent. Hepziah Partridge Billings passed away on August 21, 1865.
citation_of_attendance:
1811 List of Subscribers, in Ist Vol. 'Universal History' (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 To 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903.
Hepzibah Partridge's name is found on Hylah Bevier's list of students in her 1811 edition of 'Universal History'(Locust Grove Estate).
additional_notes: Hepzibah Partridge Billings is buried in Hatfield, Massachusetts.

name: Mary Ann Patten Munson
biographical_notes: Mary Ann Patten Munson, daughter of Nathaniel and Sarah Burt Patten, was born in 1803. In 1817 Mary Ann travelled from her hometown of Hartford, Connecticut to Litchfield, Connecticut where she attended Sarah Pierce's school until 1819. Three years after finishing her education she married Dr. Alfred Shepard Munson on May 22, 1822. Mary Ann and Alfred had six children during their marriage. Mary Ann passed away in 1887.
citation_of_attendance:
'Catalogue of the Ladies Academy in Litchfield' 1818 by J.A. Shepard (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
Mary Ann wrote an inscription and signed her name in Louisa Lewis's album that she kept while attending the Female Academy (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
1817 Litchfield Female Academy Winter Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).
1819 Litchfield Female Academy Winter Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).
secondary_sources: Baldwin, Thomas Williams. Patten Genealogy. T.W. Baldwin, 1908.

name: Alfred Shepard Munson

On November 8, 1845 Jane married George Hoxie of Kinderhook, New York.

name: Betsey Pease
biographical_notes: Betsey Pease of Suffield, Connecticut was the daughter of Seth and Bathsheba Kent Pease. In 1802 Betsey attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. No other information is known about her life at this time.
citation_of_attendance: A 'Miss Pease' is mentioned in Maryann Bacon's 1802 Journal that she kept while attending the Female Academy (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Harriet Cornelia Peck
biographical_notes: On December 9, 1814 Harriet Cornelia Peck was born to Chauncey and Minerva Bidwell Peck. In 1829 Harriet studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in her hometown of Litchfield, Connecticut.
citation_of_attendance: 1829 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Emily Peck Root
biographical_notes: Emily Peck Root of New Haven, Connecticut was born October 24, 1803. In 1819 Emily's parents, Ebenezer and Rebecca Peck, sent her to Litchfield, Connecticut to receive a formal education at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. She later married Rev. Judson Adoniram Root and passed away in 1869.
citation_of_attendance: 1819 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Grace Peck Butler
biographical_notes: Grace Peck Butler was the daughter of Ebenezer and Rebecca Dickerman Peck of New Haven, Connecticut. Born on September 1, 1801, Grace studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut in 1816. Nine years later she wed William C. Butler. Little else is known about Grace's life until her deaht on April 8, 1870.
citation_of_attendance: 1816 Litchfield Female Academy Catalog (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 To 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Harriet Peck
biographical_notes: On January 4, 1806 Harriet Peck was born to Ebenezer and Rebecca Dickerman Peck of New Haven, Connecticut. In 1821 Harriet studied at the Litchfield Female Academy, as her sisters Grace and Emily had done before her.
citation_of_attendance: 1821 Litchfield Female Academy Catalog Summer Session (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Helen Peck
biographical_notes: Helen Peck, born July 16, 1802, was the daughter of Virgil and Mary Wallace Peck of Litchfield, Connecticut. From 1814-1818 Helen studied at the Litchfield Female Academy, as her sister Mary and brother Virgil did as well. Helen's life was cut short however, and she passed away while a student.
citation_of_attendance:
Helen is mentioned in Caroline Chester's 1815-1816 diary (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).
She is also mentioned in Mary Wilbor's 1822 diary (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The Univeristy Press, 1903).
'Rules of the School and Family' and Names of the Young Ladies belonging to Miss Pierce's School in the Summer of 1814 (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
1816 Litchfield Female Academy Catalog (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).
'Catalogue of the Ladies Academy in Litchfield' 1818 by J.A. Shepard (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
additional_notes: Helen's paternal grandfather Timothy Peck was a subscriber to the Litchfield Female Academy in 1798.
quotes: 'Many of her female companions had convened . . . Her voice, tho' feeble, seemed angelic & she seemed desirous to commence on Earth the music of heaven. She joined in singing 'Vital Spark of heavenly flame' & She fully believed herself to be dying, & desirous to Spend every moment She had to live, in warning & counseling others. This continued until sometime after sunrise when She was persuaded to desist & take a little repose. Such a weeping Auditory, I never beheld, & I will only add that it seemed as if the Impression could never be effaced.'  - Col. Benjamin Tallmadge, upon attending to Helen Peck's death bed -Letter, Tallmadge to John Paine Cushman, 28 May 1822 (Litchfield Historical Society - Tallmadge Collection).

name: Levinia Peck Wanzer
biographical_notes: Levinia Peck Wanzer of North East, New York was the daughter of Noah and Belinda Peck. In 1831 she received a formal education in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. She later married Michael Wanzer, and the couple lived in Zanesville, Ohio.
citation_of_attendance: 1831 Litchfield Female Academy Winter Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Silence Peet Buell
biographical_notes: Silence Peet Bueel, daughter of Abijah Curtis Peet of Salisbury, Connecticut, and his wife Silence Leavitt Peet, was born April 16, 1813. As a student of Sarah Pierce's Female Academy, Silence received her education in Litchfield, Connecticut in 1827. While little else is known about Silence's life, historic records show that on September 6, 1836 she wed a man by the name of Norton J. Buell.
citation_of_attendance: 1827 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chroicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 To 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Alice Pelton DeWolf
biographical_notes: Born April 9, 1798, Alice Pelton DeWolf of Otis, Massachusetts attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1819. Seven years later she married Otis Whitman DeWolf, a farmer from Massachusetts. Alice and her husband had three children.
citation_of_attendance: 1819 Litchfield Female Academy Winter Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Elizabeth Penny Buel
biographical_notes: Elizabeth Penny Buel was the duaghter of Samuel Penny, a merchant in New York, New York. From 1824-1827 Elizabeth was educated at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut, just as several of her siblings were as well. In 1835 Elizabeth married Peter Buel of Litchfield, and the couple had five children during their marriage.

name: Anna Perkins Allen
biographical_notes: Anna Perkins Allen was born January 24, 1807 in Warren, Ohio to Simon and Nancy Bishop Perkins. From 1821 until 1823 Anna attended the Litchfield Female Academy. While studying in Connecticut she boarded at Miss Pierce's house and shared a room with Mary Wilbor and Harriet Buel. Four years after completing her studies Anna married John William Allen. Their marriage was cut short however when Anna died the next year.
citation_of_attendance:
Anna wrote an inscription and signed her name in Martha Dwight Denison's album while attending the Female Academy (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Mary Perkins Rockwell
biographical_notes: On August 26, 1804 Mary Perkins Rockwell was born to Joseph and Mary Watkinson Perkins of Norwich, Connecticut. As a young woman in 1818 and 1819 Mary received a formal education at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. Several years later she married John Arnold Rockwell, a lawyer and politician from Norwich, on September 28, 1831. During their marriage the couple had five children. After a full life she passed away on February 9, 1887.

'Catalogue of the Ladies Academy in Litchfield' 1818 by J.A. Shepard (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy Collection).

name: Olive Perkins Kinsman
biographical_notes: Olive Perkins Kinsman, born January 31, 1809, was the daughter of Simon and Nancy Bishop Perkins of Warren, Ohio. From 1823-1825 she attended the Litchfield Female Academy, like her older sister Anna had done. On February 1, 1832 she married Frederick W. Kinsman, a businessman and land surveyor. Olive and Frederick had three children before Olive's death in 1838.

biographical_notes: Sarah Perkins Faxon of West Hartford, Connecticut attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1827. Born march 24, 1812, she was the daughter of Timothy and Sarah Perkins. On January 31, 1832 Sarah was married to Lewis Faxon of West Hartford. After their marriage, the couple relocated to Quincy, Illinois and had three children. Sarah passed away in Payson, Illinois on September 30, 1866.

name: Mary Perry
biographical_notes: On August 4, 1785 Mary Perry was born to David and Jerusha Lord Perry of Richmond, Massachusetts. It is believed that around the year 1800 she may have attended the Litchfield Female Academy, as her sister Sarah did several years later. No other information is known about Mary's life until her death on April 7, 1865.
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]

name: Nancy Perry Merrick
biographical_notes: Nancy Perry Merrick was born December 10, 1816 to Ezra and Vashti Peck Perry of Brimfield, Massachusetts. In 1832 Nancy received a formal education in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Nine years later she married Samuel D. Merrick of Sturbridge, Massachusetts on November 29, 1841.
citation_of_attendance: 1832 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Sarah Perry Gates
biographical_notes: Sarah Perry Gates was one of three daughters to attend the Litchfield Female Academy. The daughter of Rev. David Perry and his wife Jerusha Lord Perry, Sarah was born August 16, 1793. In 1818 and 1822 she studied in Litchfield at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. On January 17, 1822 she married Samuel Gates, a businessman and manufacturer from Richmond, Massachusetts. On August 20, 1856 Sarah passed away.
citation_of_attendance: 'Catalogue of the Ladies Academy in Litchfield' 1818 by J.A. Shepard (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
materials: Litchfield Female Academy Collection;Sampler by Sarah Perry Gates

name: Mary A. Peters
biographical_notes: Mary A. Peter of Hartford, Connecticut was the daughter of John Thompson Peters and his wife Elizabeth Caulkins Peters. In 1819 Mary, along with her sister Abigail, attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut.
citation_of_attendance: 1819 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Clarinda Pettibone Holcomb
biographical_notes: Clarinda Pettibone Holcomb is believed to have attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1798. The daughter of Chauncey and Theodosia Hayes Pettibone of Granby, Connecticut, Clarinda was born January 19, 1781. On January 3, 1803 she married Thomas Holcomb of Granby, Connecticut, and the couple had six children. She passed away on October 17, 1885.
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]

name: Harriot Pettibone
biographical_notes: Harriot Pettibone of Norfolk, Connecticut was the daughter of Augustus and Susan Curtis Pettibone. Augustus, a lawyer and politician, had studied at the Litchfield Law School as a young man. Following this tradition he sent his daughter Harriot to study in Litchfield at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in 1802.
citation_of_attendance:
Harriot is listed as a fellow student in Maryann Bacon's 1802 Journal (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
1802 Litchfield Female Academy Catalog (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Susannah Pettibone
biographical_notes: Susannah Pettibone, born October 23, 1795, was the daughter of Giles and Louisa Pettibone of Norfolk, Connecticut. Around the year 1810 Susannah received a formal education in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy.
citation_of_attendance: Susannah completed a mourning pictures while studying at the Litchfield Female Acadmey (Norfolk Historical Society).

name: Amos Pettingill, Jr.
biographical_notes: Amos Pettingill, Jr. of Morris, Connecticut attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1822.
citation_of_attendance:
1822 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).
He is mentioned in Mary L. Wilbor's 1822 Diary. (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Charlotte Pettit
biographical_notes: Charlotte Pettit of Wilton, Connecticut attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1814. No other information is known about her identity at this time.
citation_of_attendance: 'Rules of the School and Family' and Names of the Young Ladies belonging to Miss Pierce's School in the Summer of 1814 (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Charlotte Phelps Cowles
biographical_notes: Charlotte Phelps Cowles, daughter of Noah Loomis Phelps and Jemima Stedman Phelps of Farmington, Connecticut, was born April 10, 1809. In 1825 and 1826 Charlotte studied at the Litchfield Female Academy, and five her later married George Deming Cowles of Farmington. George had served in the Connecticut Militia prior to their marriage, and later worked as a druggist and postmaster. During their marriage Charlotte and George had seven children.
citation_of_attendance:
1826 Litchfield Female Academy Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).
'Copy of Rules' of the Litchfield Female Academy written by Charlotte Phelps (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).
secondary_sources: Phelps, Oliver Seymour and Andrew Tinkey Servin. The Phelps Family of America and Their English Ancestors. Pittsfield, MA: Eagle Publishing Co., 1899.

name: Lucy Ann Phelps
biographical_notes: Lucy Ann Phelps was born on January 19, 1812 to Walter and Julia Beach Phelps of New York City. In 1824 Lucy travelled to Litchfield, Connecticut where she spent a short time studying at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Only three year later on March 18, 1827 Lucy passed away.
citation_of_attendance: 1824 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Polly Phelps Wilmot
biographical_notes: Polly Phelps Wilmot was the daughter of John and Sally Shethar Phelps of Litchfield, Connecticut. Because Polly's sister Sarah had attended the Female Academy, and because they were a local family it is likely that she studied in Litchfield as well. During her life she married twice. First to Caleb Croswell, with whom she had one child. And second to Walker Wilmot, whom she had four children with.
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]

name: Sarah Phelps Riley
other_name: Sarah Phelps; Sally Phelps; Sally Riley
biographical_notes: Sarah Phelps Riley was born on July 4, 1787 to John and Sally Shethar Phelps of Litchfield, Connecticut. In 1800 Sarah received a formal education in her hometown at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Several years later she married John C. Riley on December 6, 1844. Sarah passed away in 1870.
citation_of_attendance: Sarah completed a needlework titled 'Autumn' while attending the Litchfield Female Academy (Litchfield Historical Society).

name: Mary Pierce Pettee
biographical_notes: Mary Pierce Pettee of Salisbury, Connecticut was born on February 21, 1807. Her father, James Pierce, was the half-brother of Sarah Pierce. In 1823 Mary travelled to Litchfield where spent a short time studying at her aunt's school. Several years later she married Rev. Joseph Pettee of Salisbury on February 24, 1835. Mary and Joseph had six children.
citation_of_attendance: 1823 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Joseph Pettee
other_education: Graduated from Yale in 1833 and attended Yale Divinity School

name: Nancy Maria Pierce
biographical_notes: Nancy Maria Pierce of Salisbury, Connecticut was born on February 20, 1811. Her father, James Pierce, was the half-brother of Sarah Pierce. In 1826 Nancy travelled to Litchfield where spent a short time studying at her aunt's school, as her sister Mary had three years earlier.
citation_of_attendance: 1826 Litchfield Female Academy Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Elizabeth Pierpont Langdon
biographical_notes: Elizabeth Pierpont Langdon, born May 28, 1790, was the daughter of James and Elizabeth Collins Pierpont. In 1807 she studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in her hometown of Litchfield, Connecticut. On March 5, 1815 she married John Langdon, an educator and minister from Bethlehem, Connecticut. During their marriage Elizabeth and John had four children. Elizabeth passed away only eight years after their marriage.
citation_of_attendance: Sarah Beekman's May 17 - August jounral of 1807 mentions Miss Pierpont. This girl was likely Elizabeth Pierpont. (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Esther Pierpont Sheldon
biographical_notes: Esther and Calvin had five children. Esther's mother Lois Collins was the daughter of Charles and Anne Huntington Collins who married in 1752. Charles was the son of Reverand Timothy Collins, the first minister of Litchfield's Congregational Church.

name: Julia Pierpont Warn
biographical_notes: Julia Pierpont Warn of Manchester, Vermont was born in 1793. She was one of several children born to Robert and Lois Collins Pierpont.  In 1808 it is believed that Julia may have attended the Litchfield Female Academy. She later married Richard Henry Warn.
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]
additional_notes: Julia's mother Lois Collins was the daughter of Charles and Anne Huntington Collins who were married in 1752. Charles was the son of Reverand Timothy Collins, the first minister of Litchfield's Congregational Church.

name: Laura Pierpont Sperry
biographical_notes: Born in 1791, Laura Pierpont Sperry was the daughter of Robert and Lois Collins Pierpont of Manchester, Vermont. It is believed that prior to 1812 Laura may have attended the Litchfield Female Academy as her sisters did. In 1812 she married Anson J. Sperry
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]
additional_notes: Laura's mother Lois Collins was the daughter of Charles and Anne Huntington Collins who married in 1752. Charles was the son of Reverand Timothy Collins, the first minister of Litchfield's Congregational Church.

name: Mary Elizabeth Pierpont
biographical_notes: Mary Elizabeth Pierpont, daughter of John and Mary Lord Pierpont of Boston, Massachusetts, was born September 18, 1812. In 1824 Mary received a formal educaiton in Litchfield, Connecticut as both of her parents had done several years earlier. Little else is known about Mary's life until her death in 1857.
citation_of_attendance: 1824 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).
private_notes: The Pierpont Morgan Library may have an autograph album (1826-1835) of Mary's.

name: Minerva Pierpont Woodward
biographical_notes: Minerva Pierpont Woodward of Plymouth, Connecticut was born September 4, 1809. She was the daughter of Sherman and Sidney Humiston Pierpont. In 1825 Minerva received a formal education in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Two years later she married Sherman P. Woodward on November 27, 1827, and had two children.
citation_of_attendance: 1825 Litchfield Female Academy Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).
additional_notes: Minerva and Sherman's daughter Rachel attended the Fort Edward Seminary and was a teacher in Pennsylvania.

name: Nancy Pierpont Isham
biographical_notes: Nancy Pierpont Isham was the daughter of Robert and Lois Collins Pierpont of Manchester, Vermont. It is believed that around the year 1799 Nancy may have attended the Litchfield Female Academy. Sometime after she would have completed her studies, and prior to 1801 Nancy married Ezra Isham.
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]

name: Eliza Pitkin
biographical_notes: Eliza Pitkin of East Hartford, Connecticut was born October 20, 1800. In 1816 her parents, John and Priscilla Hyde Pitkin, sent her to Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut to sudy. Several years later Eliza married Daniel Pitkin, a lawyer and politician from East Hartford, on April 7, 1831. Eliza passed away in 1869.
citation_of_attendance: 1816 Litchfield Female Academy Catalog (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Charlotte Platt Hewitt
biographical_notes: Charlotte Platt Hewitt, born January 25, 1800, was the daughter of businessman Jonathan Platt and his wife Anna Brush. In 1816 and 1817 she travelled from her hometown of Owego, New York to Litchfield, Connecticut where she studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. On May 17, 1821 she married Gurdon Hewitt, and the couple had four children. Charlotte passed away on January 16, 1876.
citation_of_attendance:
1816 Litchfield Female Academy Catalog (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Eliza Pledger
biographical_notes: Eliza Pledger of Middletown, Connecticut was the daughter of Jacob and Sarah Watkinson Pledger. While little is known about Eliza's life, it is documented that in 1814 she attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut.
citation_of_attendance:
'Rules of the School and Family' and Names of the Young Ladies belonging to Miss Pierce's School in the Summer of 1814 (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
A student wrote an inscription and signed their name 'Eliza P' in Marian Lewis 1814 album - this student could possibly be Eliza Pledger (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Ann Porter Ward
biographical_notes: Ann Porter Ward of Hartford, Connecticut was the daughter of Solomon and Nancy Belding Porter. In 1830 Ann attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. Six years after completing her studies she married William Andrew Ward, and the couple had two children.
citation_of_attendance: 'Catalogue of the Litchfield Academy … 1830' (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy Collection).

name: Solomon Porter
other_education: Attended Hartford Academy and Yale College

name: Belinda Porter Leland
biographical_notes: Belinda Porter Leland of Plattsburgh, New York was born October 15, 1802. In 1819 her parents, Robert and Roxanna Root Porter, sent her to Litchfield, Connecticut to study at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. On September 29, 1824 Belinda married Ziba Abba Leland. After their marriage Ziba worked as a lawyer and the couple had five children. Belinda passed away on March 26, 1842.
citation_of_attendance: 1819 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Ziba Abba Leland
other_education: Attended the University of Vermont in 1815 and 1816, and attended Middlebury College from 1816 to 1818

name: Cornelia Porter
biographical_notes: Cornelia Porter was the daughter of businessman Joseph Porter and his wife Miss Barton Porter. In 1827 Cornelia travelled from her hometown of Utica, New York to Litchfield, Connecticut where she spent two years studying at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy with her sister Elizabeth.

name: Laura Porter Hill
biographical_notes: Laura Porter Hill, born April 22, 1796, was the daughter of Rev. David and Sarah Collins Porter. It is believed that in 1811 Laura journeyed from you hometown of Catskill, New York to Litchfield, Connecticut to study at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. On July 30, 1821 she married a gentleman named Henry Hill.
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]
additional_notes: Laura Porter Hill of Catskill, New York is listed as a subscriber to Sarah Pierce's text 'Universal History' in 1811. It is known that not all subscribers necessarily attended the school. Until a solid citation of attendance can be found Eliza will be considered a possible student. -1811 List of Subscribers in Ist Vol. 'Universal History' (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. name: Elizabeth Prince Child
biographical_notes: Elizabeth Prince Child, daughter of Charles and Anna Culter Prince of Watertown, New York, was born around the year 1815. From 1830 until 1832 Elizabeth received her education in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. She later married Nathaniel Rochetser Child of Rochester, New York on June 26, 1844. During their marriage the couple had two children, one boy and one girl. After her husband's death, she moved to Litchfield and spent the remainder of her life living at the Sheldon House on North Street with her first cousin once removed, and fellow Litchfield Female Academy student Lucy Sheldon Beach.

On August 18, 1829 Catherine married Harmon Pruyn Van Valkenburgh and the couple had nine children.

name: Roxana Purdy Crane
biographical_notes: Roxana Purdy Crane, daughter of Isaac and Lydia Clift Purdey of North Salem, New York, was born June 21 of either 1804 or 1805. In 1821 and 1822 Roxana received a formal education at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut along with her sister Clarissa. After completing her studies she married Gerard Crane of North Salem, New York in October of 1823. During their marriage, the couple resided in Somers, New York and had seven children. Roxana passed away on January 24, 1867.

name: Belinda Radcliffe Hollister
biographical_notes: Belinda Radcliffe Hollister was one of several children to attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Born in 1810, she was the daughter of Jerry and Arianda Webster Radcliffe of Buffalo, New York. In 1829 Belinda receive a formal education in Litchfield. Four years later she married Robert Hollister, a businessman originally from Pittsfield, Massachusetts. Belinda passed away in 1874.
citation_of_attendance: 1829 Litchfield Female Academy Winter Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Delia Radcliffe Kipp
biographical_notes: Delia Radcliffe Kipp, daughter of Jerry and Arianda Webster Radcliffe, was born November 15, 1815. Delia was one of five children to attended the Litchfield Female Academy, and she began her three years of study in 1829. On August 24, 1837 she married Thomas Kipp of Buffalo, New York. During their marriage the couple had four children. Delia passed away a decade later.

biographical_notes: Ann Maria Randall, born August 28, 1795, was the daughter of Jonathan and Catherine Meyer Randall of New York City. Anna's father Jonathan at one time owned Randall's Island. name: Phoebe Rapalje Bowne
biographical_notes: Pheobe Rapalje Bown, daughter of Abraham Brinckerhoff Rapalje and his wife Mary Schouten Rapalje of Fishkill, New York, was born October 21, 1796. In 1811 Phoebe was sent to Litchfield, Connecticut where she spent time studying at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. In either 1822 or 1823 Phoebe married Samuel Bowne, a businessman in Fishkill, with whom she had one child. During their marriage, Samuel and Phoebe resided in Fishkill, where Samuel owned and operated a store on Main Street. On October 10, 1880 Phoebe passed away.
citation_of_attendance: List of students kept by Hylah Bevier in her 1811 edition of 'Universal History' (Locust Grove Estate).

name: Tapping Burr Reeve
biographical_notes: Tapping Burr Reeve, son of Aaron Burr Reeve and his wife Annabella, was born August 16, 1809. His grandfather, Tapping Reeve, had founded the Litchfield Law School, which is father had attended. From 1817-1824 Tapping studied in his hometown at the Litchfield Female Academy, as his half-siblings Harriet and William would do as well. He later attended Yale, and passed away at a young age in 1829.

name: Betsy Reynolds Voorhees
biographical_notes: Born in December 9, 1790, Betsy Reynolds Voorhees was the daughter of Dr. Stephen and Lydia Bartlett Reynolds of Florida, Montgomery County, New York. Both her parents had roots in Litchfield County. From 1806-1807 Betsy attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. While there Betsey kept a journal which has survived. Four years after completing her studies she married Dr. Samuel Voorhees, whom she met while he was studying with her father. They began married life in Charleston, NY before moving across the river from the village of Amsterdam, New York in 1820. Between 1812 and 1826 they had four son.    She was a very dedicated mother, following the teachings of Sarah Pierce; an accomplished needlewoman; and a social reformer. She was active in the Magdalen Society, Colored Orphan's Asylum, the Tombs, Blackwell's Island, Foreign American Antislavery Society and the women's rights movement. She submitted examples of her needlework to the New York State Agricultural Society Fair and the American Institute and was a frequent recipient of prizes.   Betsy passed away in 1858.
citation_of_attendance: Betsy kept a journal while attending the Litchfield Female Academy (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
additional_notes: John Pierce Brace wrote a short poem about Betsy Reynolds in 1806 - 'History of My Poetry Vol. I' (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).    Primary sources for Betsy Reynolds Voorhees are located in the Litchfield Female Academy collection, Series 2: Student Papers, Records, and Documents, Folders 92 and 93.
private_notes: Montgomery County Historical Society at Fort Johnson, NY contacted by JLeone 12/6/10 by phone. They own a portrait and several watercolors. They have a publication, 'What a Rich Reward: Betsey Reynolds Voorhees and the Collection of Her Handiwork,' of which a copy is in the LHS Library.
quotes: '. . . after school took a walk to the post office, but not with an idea of getting a letter so that I was no disappointed, were I not one of those contented sort, perfectly easy in almost every situation I should doubtlessly be very unhappy, as I have not heard from home either directly or indirectly this two months past, but I will only look at the best side and consider they have nothing new to inform me, but I can assure them that their advice is always acceptable and of this I am always in want.' Betsey Reynold's diary (LHS).

name: Samuel Voorhees
biographical_notes: Samuel Voorhees family migrated from Monmouth County, New Jersey to Montgomery County, New York following the American Revolution.  He attended Union College in Schnectady, New York.  After choosing to pursue a career in medicine he studied with Dr. Stephen Reynolds, who as president of the Montgomery County Medical Society signed his medical degree on October 10, 1810.  He met his future wife, Betsey, while studying with her father.  They were married on April 24, 1811.  They had four sons.

No other information is known about Elizabeth's life until her death in 1844.

'C Rockwell' is noted as a cast member in a handwritten copy of the play 'Two Cousins' by Sarah Pierce (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Henry Ensign Rockwell
biographical_notes: Born March 24, 1811, Henry Ensign Rockwell was the son of Elijah and Sophia Ensign Rockwell of Canaan, Connecticut. As a young man Henry received a formal education in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. During his lifetime Henry married twice. First to Emerett Munson on November 2, 1837, and later to Saram Hathaway on January 30, 1854. He also spent his life working as an educator and resided in Millbury, Massachusetts and Washington, D.C. Henry passed away in 1882 on March 22.
citation_of_attendance: 'Catalogue of the Litchfield Academy … 1830' (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy Collection).

name: Susan Rockwell Pierce
biographical_notes: Susan and George had six children
citation_of_attendance: 1816 Litchfield Female Academy Catalog (ENV Chronicles Appendix D) Mary Phelps noted in her copy of the catalog that Susan Rockwell had 'married.'
quotes: In June 1816, Rockwell and fellow Litchfield Female Academy students Caroline Chester and Miss Sanford hired a carriage for an afternoon drive. While passing Tapping Reeve's house on South Street, Chester realized they had another passenger, Litchfield Law Student John Robbins Pitt, who was playing a joke on the group:    'In turning around saw sitting on the back of the carriage Mr. Pitt, I was astonished that a person whom I imagined possessed so much dignity would condescend to be seen in such a degraded situation, but what was my surprise when he cried out in a voice resembling some low bred country clown -- 'Don't whip behind.' Miss R______ immediately stopped the carriage & he jumped off...'

name: George Edmond Pierce
other_education: Graduated from Yale in 1816, attended Andover Theological Seminary, and received his Doctor of Divinity degree from Middlebury College in 1838

name: Miss Roe
biographical_notes: In 1816 a student named Miss Rose attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Whlie studying in Litchfield she boarded at Mrs. Bull's house.
citation_of_attendance: Mentioned in Eliza Ogden 1816-1818 diary (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Abby Rogers Fort
biographical_notes: Abby Rogers Fort was the daughter of James and Betsey Berry Rogers of Saratoga, New York. Born on May 16, 1805, she attended the Litchfield Female Academy from 1819-1821. Two years after completing her studies she married Abraham Fort, a businessman of Fortsville, New York.
citation_of_attendance:

name: Abigail Rogers Pratt
biographical_notes: Abigail Rogers Pratt of Cornwall, Connecticut was born August 28, 1805 to Noah and Lydia Cornwall Rogers. In 1821 Abigail travelled to nearby Litchfield, Connecticut where she spent a short time attending Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. She later married Eliakim Pratt of Cornwall. The couple had five children and later resided in Flint, Michigan.
citation_of_attendance: 1821 Litchfield Female Academy Catalog Summer Session (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Noah Rogers, IV
marriages: Lydia Cornwell Rogers/1789;Elizabeth Wilson Rogers/June 22, 1810;Abigail Humphrey Rogers/November 11, 1829

name: Elizabeth Rogers Norton
other_name: Elizabeth Wilson Rogers; Eliza Rogers; Eliza Norton
biographical_notes: Eliza Rogers was the daughter of Deacon Noah Rogers and his wife Elizabeth, of Cornwall, CT. In 1828 she attended the Litchfield Female Academy, and shortly after completing her studies married Reverend Augustus Norton who at the time was preaching in Windham, NY. During the course of their marriage they had five children. In 1835 Eliza and Augustus moved to Naples, Illinois and spent several years moving through central and southern Illinois as Augustus worked to establish several Presbyterian churches. In 1839 they settled in Alton, IL where for nineteen years Augustus preached at the First Presbyterian Church. In 1859 they moved their family to Chicago for a short time, but by 1861 they had returned to Alton to live the remainer of their lives.
citation_of_attendance: 1828 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (ENV Chronicles Appendix D page 428)
residences: Windham/NY/United States;Naples/IL/United States;Griggsville/IL/United States;St. Louis/MO/United States;Alton/IL/United States;Chicago/IL/United States

name: Augustus Theodore Norton
other_education: Graduated from Yale in 1832, and received his Doctor of Divinity degree from Wabash College in 1868

name: Miss Rogers
biographical_notes: In 1802 a student named Miss Rogers attended the Litchfield Female Academy. No other information is known about this student's identity at this time.
citation_of_attendance: A 'Miss Rogers' is mentioned in Maryann Bacon's 1802 Journal that she kept while attending the Female Academy (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy Collection).

name: Rhoda Rogers Hart
biographical_notes: Rhoda Rogers Hart, daughter of Noah Rogers, VI and his first wife Lydia Cornwell Rogers, was born on June 9, 1798. In 1814 she left her hometown of Cornwall, Connecticut to attend school in nearby Litchfield at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. On January 7, 1819 Rhoda married Julius Hart.
citation_of_attendance: 1814 Summer Session Litchfield Female Academy Catalog (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Amarette Root Case
biographical_notes: Amarette Root Case was the daughter of Joel and Clarissa Ensign Root of Granville, Massachusetts. In 1831 Amarette attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. Several years later, in October of 1850, she married Horatio Nelson Case. The couple resided in Springfield, Massachusetts and had one child.
citation_of_attendance: 1831 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 To 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Sarah Root Moore
biographical_notes: On May 16, 1812 Sarah Root Moore was born to Joel and Clarissa Ensign Root of Granville, Massachusetts. In 1831 Sarah and her sister Amarette received formal educations in Litchfield, Connecticut at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. On October 8, 1841 she married Roger Sherman moore, a lawyer and businessman from Southwick, Massachusetts. After their marriage Sarah and Roger had one child, and resided in Springfield, Massachusetts.
citation_of_attendance: 1831 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Charlotte Rose Holly
biographical_notes: Charlotte Rose Holly was the daughter of politican William Lucius Rose and his wife Charlotte Smith of New York City. Born in 1798 she attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1811 and 1812. Three years later on July 25, 1815 she married William Coggeshall Holly of Stamford, Connecticut. During their marriage the couple had seven children. Charlotte passed away on April 9, 1876.
citation_of_attendance: John Pierce Brace, 'History of My Poetry Vol. II' (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
quotes: 'Last night about eight, there was a message came to me to go down to the Farms for Cornelia [Van Kleek], Charlotte [Rose] and Juliana [McLachlan] who had staid there. Their horse had tired out, so that Nancy Starkweather, Mary Griswold and Mary Bulkley who would not stay, came up, partly on foot, and partly in the cutter leaving the other girls at a tavern under the protection of Alexander McLachlan (a little boy). Father would not let me go. Today I hear a vast many different stories that I do not know which I believe. Some say they wanted to stay & some say they did not. After meeting they came up.' - John Pierce Brace, 'History of My Poetry Vol. II' (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).

name: Catharine C. Russell
biographical_notes: On April 8, 1811 Catharine C. Russell was born to Emanuel and Betsey Williams Russell of Litchfield, Connecticut. In 1826 Catharine attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy, and her brother Isaac studied at the school the following year.
citation_of_attendance: 1826 Litchfield Female Academy Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Isaac Russell
biographical_notes: On May 2, 1807 Isaac Russell was born to Emanuel and Betsey Williams Russell of Litchfield, Connecticut. In 1827 Isaac received a formal education at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy as his sister Catharine had done the year prior.

name: Lucy Russell Hill
biographical_notes: Lucy Russell Hill, born July 12, 1785, attended the Litchfield Female Academy from 1799-1806. She was the daughter of Samuel and Lucy Munson Russell of New York, New York, an married a name man Henry Hill the year after completing her studies.
citation_of_attendance: Lucy completed a silk embroidery titled 'Flora' while a student at the Litchfield Female Academy (Litchfield Historical Society).    Letter, 1 Feb 1800, Clarissa Champion to Dorothy Deming. - Deming, Perkins, and Quincy Family paper, 1762-1950, Litchfield Historical Society.

name: Olive Russell Webb
biographical_notes: Olive Russell Webb of Salisbury, Connecticut was born August 14, 1804. She was the daughter of John and Charity Russell. In 1822 Olive attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. She later married Sidney B. Webb of Hamilton, New York.
citation_of_attendance:

name: Joseph Merrill Sadd
other_education: Attended Stockbridge Academy, graduated from William College in 1827, and attended Auburn Theological Seminary from 1827-1830.
biographical_notes: Joseph Merrill Sadd, born November 6, 1801, was the son of Harvey and Lydia Merrill Sadd of Winchester, Connecticut. In 1819 Joseph studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. As a young man Joseph also studied at the Stockbridge Academy, and in 1827 he graduated from Williams College. After completing his studied at Williams he began studying at Auburn Theological Seminary, and in 1830 was ordained. In July of 1830 Joseph married Corinne Gilmore. After their marriage Joseph continued working as an educator, missionary, and minister, and the couple resided in various locations around the country.
citation_of_attendance: 1819 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Ann Catharine Salisbury
biographical_notes: Ann Catharine Salisbury of Catskill, New York was born in 1808 or 1809. As a young woman she attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1816. Nothing else is known about Ann's life at time, except her death on May 19, 1895.
citation_of_attendance: 1816 Litchfield Female Academy Catalog (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

Elizabeth and Elias later resided in Kingston, New Brunswick, Canada and had six children. She passed away on December 18, 1869.

biographical_notes: Orra Sears Cook was the daughter of Jasper Peck Sears of West Bloomfield, New York, and his wife Martha Parsons Sears. In 1816 Orra traveled to Litchfield, Connecticut where she boarded at Lyman Beecher's house while attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Many years later, on April 27, 1841 Orra married Edwin Cook. The couple resided in Tonawanda, New York.

name: Sybil Sears Hamlin
biographical_notes: Sybil Sears Hamlin, daughter of John and Almira Gould Sears of Sharon, Connecticut, was born September 22, 1813. In 1828 and 1830 she studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. Sybil married twice during her life. First to Henry W. Blackman. After his death she was remarried to Henry William Hamlin of East Bloomfield, New York. She had six children, and passed away on July 15, 1870.
citation_of_attendance:
'Catalogue of the Litchfield Academy ... 1830' (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
Sybil wrote an inscription and signed her name 'S.B. Sears' in Catherine Williams's 1830 album while attending the Litchfield Female Academy (Litchfield Female Academy - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
1828 Litchfield Female Academy Summer Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Mary Sebor Sheldon
biographical_notes: Mary Sebor Sheldon was born on March 24, 1798 to Jacob and Elizabeth Winthrop Sebor of Middletown, Connecticut. In 1813 Mary attended Rev. Claus Herrick's female school in New Haven, Connecticut. It is also believed that she may have attended the Litchfield Female Academy. On October 17, 1820 she married Frederick Sheldon of New York City. During their marriage Frederick worked as a businessman and the couple had two children. On November 14, 1850, at the age of fifty-two, Mary passed away from breast cancer.

name: Frederick Sheldon
biographical_notes: On March 12, 1785 Frederick Sheldon was born to Dr. Daniel Sheldon and his wife Huldah Stone Sheldon. Being local residents of Litchfield as well as Dr. Sheldon being a subscriber to the Litchfield Female Academy, it is likely that around 1793 Frederick attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. On October 17, 1820 Frederick married Mary Sebor Sheldon, a former student a the Litchfield Female Academy. During their marriage Frederick pursued a career in insurance and banking. He and Mary had two children. Frederick passed away on April 21, 1859.
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]
materials: An American selection of lessons in reading and speaking :

name: Thomas Seeley
biographical_notes: Thomas Seeley was the son of Seth and Abigail Taylor Seeley. In 1830 he travelled from his hometown of Danbury, Connecticut to Litchfield, Connecticut where he studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Thomas later became a doctor and married Sarah Deming Seeley. The couple resided in Woodbury, Connecticut.
citation_of_attendance: 'Catalogue of the Litchfield Academy … 1830' (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy Collection).

name: Elizabeth Seldon Eaton
biographical_notes: Elizabeth Seldon Eaton attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1817. Born on April 18, 1796, she was the daughter of Calvin and Phebe Ely Seldon of Lyme, Connecticut. On December 5, 1818 Elizabeth married Joseph Spencer, and the couple had one child during their marriage. After Joseph's death, she wed Amos Beebe of Rochester, New York. Elizabeth and Amos went on to have three children.
citation_of_attendance:
1817 Litchfield Female Academy Winter Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).
Elizabeth Seldon is mentioned as a fellow student by Fanny Lord in an interview given to Emily Noyes Vanderpoel in 1899 (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Amelia Seymour Sanford
biographical_notes: Amelia Seymour Sanford, daughter of Ozias Seymour, of Litchfield, Connecticut was born March 6, 1809. From 1821-1824 and again in 1827 Amelia attended the Litchfield Female Academy as her mother, Salima Storrs Seymour had as a young woman. Three years after completing her studies Amelia married David Curtis Sanford on May 25, 1830. David, originally from New Milford, Connecticut, was as a lawyer and politician. Only three years after their marriage Amelia passed away on July 15, 1833.

name: Ann Maria Seymour Watson
biographical_notes: Ann Maria Seymour Watson was born July 10, 1815. She was the daughter of Ira and Maria Marsh Seymour of New Hartford, New York. In 1823 Ann Maria traveled to Litchfield, Connecticut where she studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. Several years later she married Edmund Watson on January 27, 1836.
citation_of_attendance: 1832 Litchfield Female Academy Winter Session Catalogue (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1903).

name: Clarissa Seymour Roby
biographical_notes: Clarissa Seymour Roby, daughter of Samuel and Rebecca Osborn Seymour, was born January 23, 1800 in Litchfield, Connecticut. In 1798 Clarissa's father was a subscriber to the Litchfield Female Academy, and in 1814 he had Clarissa educated at the institution. Several years later she married Thomas R. Roby of Brockport, New York on October 22, 1828.
citation_of_attendance:

name: Samuel Seymour
biographical_notes:
Samuel Seymour was the son of Moses and Rachel (Goodwin) Seymour of Hartford, CT. He was the seventh of eight children. In 1775, Samuel enlisted in the Continential Army and under the leadership of Col David Waterbury marched on New York City. His company was dismissed two months later and he returned to Hartford. In 1776, he moved to Litchfield, CT and re-enlisted in a company of troops commandec by Capt. Nathaniel Goodwin. This company was involved in the Battle of King's Bridge in Westchester County, NY. By April 1777, he had again been discharged and returned to Litchfield. Upon hearing that the British army intended to march on Danbury and destroy the city, Samuel marched with a company under the command of Eaton Jones towards to defend the city. By the time the company had reached Danbury, the city had been burned. The company chased the British through Ridgefield and towards the Long Island Sound. Several skirmishes arose until the British reached the safety of their ships.
Soon afterwards he was elected Sergeant of the company commanded by Capt. Miles Beach and placed in charge of a group of men to guard ammunition and provisions held at the supply depot in Litchfield. He was actively involved in military campaigns throughout the Revolutionary War, rising the rank of Captain.
When the Revolutionary War ended, Samuel returned to Litchfield and went into business with his brother Moses making hats. Samuel married Rebecca Osborn in 1788 and they had six children.

name: Rebecca Osborn Seymour
biographical_notes: Rebecca was the daughter of John and Lois (Peck) Osborn of Litchfield, CT. She married Samuel Seymour in 1788 and they had six children together.

name: Delia Storrs Seymour
biographical_notes: Delia Storrs Seymour, born November 25, 1806, came from a family tradition of being educated at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. As a young women her mother Mabel Strong Seymour attended the Female Acaemy in Litchfield, and in 1818, 1820, and 1821 Delia was also educated in her hometown of Litchfield. After completing her studies at Ms. Pierce's school Delia was a teacher in Stratford, Connecticut and Red Hook, New York. She later served as Principal of the Ladies' Seminary in Painesvile, Ohio. Delia passed away in 1887.

name: Eleanora Seymour Scott
biographical_notes: In 1813 Eleanora Seymour Scott was born to Israel T. and Sally Church Seymour of Troy, New York. In 1825 Eleanora studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. Eleven years later she was married to a man named Samuel B. Scott. In 1839, three years after their marriage, Eleanora passed away.

name: Epaphroditus Seymour
biographical_notes: Epaphroditus Seymour, born August 7, 1812, was the son of Moses Seymour, Jr. and his wife Mabel Strong Seymour. In 1824 and 1825 Epaphroditus was educated as Sarah Pierce's Female Academy, as his siblings were as well. Epaphroditus later married Julia Ann Hyde, and resided in Kenosha, Wisconsin and California. He passed away in 1850. His paternal grandfather Major Moses Seymour was a subscriber to the Litchfield Female Academy in 1798

name: George Seymour
biographical_notes: George Seymour of Litchfield, Connecticut was born December 27, 1816. In 1830 and 1831 his parents, Moses and Mabel Strong Seymour, had George educated at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. George later attended the Western College of Physicians and Surgeons, and after graduated began his medical practice in Litchfield. On February 10, 1841 he married Sarah Newell Hunt. George passed away in 1861.

name: Jane Seymour Beckwith
biographical_notes: Jane Seymour Beckwith, daughter of Moses Seymour, Jr. and his wife Mable Strong Seymour of Litchfield, Connecticut, was born March 7, 1811. From 1824-1828 Jane studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in her hometown. Her paternal grandfather Major Moses Seymour was a subscriber to the Litchfield Female Academy in 1798. Three years after completing her education she married Josiah Gale Beckwith, and the couple had five children during their marriage. She and her husband lived in the Moses Seymour, Jr. house on South St. in Litchfield. The house had been built by her father in 1817.

He later moved to Davenport, Iowas where he was a merchant and manufacturer. On December 26, 1853 John married Rachel Wetmore Seymour.

Coming from a family with a tradition of being educated in Litchfield, Louisa studied at the Litchfield Female Academy in 1815 and 1816, and again in 1819. On February 9, 1823 she married Stanley G. Lockwood of New Milford, Connecituct. The copule later relocated to Painesville, Ohio, and had five children. Louisa passed away in 1878.

biographical_notes: Mariana Seymour Kingsbury was one of several children to attended the Litchfield Female Academy. Born on Feburary 13, 1805, her parents were former Female Academy student Mabel Strong Seymour and Moses Seymour, Jr. From 1818-1821 Mariana attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in her hometown. Several years later she married Horace Kingsbury on Feburary 18, 1848. Mariana passed away in 1881.

name: Mary Jane Seymour Miller
biographical_notes: Mary Jane Seymour Miller was born September 15, 1807 to Henry and Mary Forman Seymour of Utica, New York. In 1821 Mary travelled to Litchfield, Connecticut where she would briefly study at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. On July 28, 1828 she wed Rutger Bleeker Miller. Rutger, from Utica as well, had studied at the Litchfield Law School and made his living as a lawyer and politician. Less than ten years after their marriage Mary passed away in 1837.

name: Moses McCure Seymour
biographical_notes: On July 13, 1814 Moses McCure Seymour was born to Moses and Mabel Strong Seymour of Litchfield, Connecticut. In 1831 Moses, like his mother and siblings, attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in his hometown. Six years later he married Maria Aiken Seymour on December 31, 1837. After moving to Pailesville, Ohio Moses served the local community as a doctor and postmaster. He passed away in 1896.

name: Eliza Shaw
biographical_notes: It is believed that Eliza Shaw of New York, New York may have attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in 1811. There is no concrete evidence at this point however to confirm her attendance at the school.
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]
additional_notes: Eliza Shaw of New York City was a subscriber to Sarah Pierce's history text 'Universal History' in 1811. It is known that not all subscriber's necessarily attended the Litchfield Female Academy.

name: William Shedden
quotes: Died- on Tuesday evening, the 13th inst. after a lingering and painful illness, which he bore with that manly fortitude and philosophy which characterises the good man and the christian, William Shedden, Esquire, and old respectable Merchant and inhabitant of this City.  It is but a small tribute due the memory of this Gentleman to say, that in him Society has sustained a loss, almost irreparable- His Philanthropy knew no bounds; his great and shining talents were uniformly excited for the good of mankind. As a Merchant, his opinions were almost equal to law; they were founded on the unerring principles, the immutable basis of Justice and of Truth. He was honest- he was honorable. Such was the man whose character we have now depicted. But, alas! To the unalterable laws of Nature, every Human Being must submit!  New York Gazette and General Advertiser; November 15, 1798 Page 2.

name: Jane E. Shedden
biographical_notes:
Jane and her sister Annabella were the illegitimate daughters of loyalist William Shedden, a prominent Pre-Revolutionary merchant in New York. The two girls had different mothers however. Jane's mother married William Shedden but only after having Jane and another child, William out of wedlock. Under American law this legitimized Jane and her brother William, however under English law they were still considered illegimiate. By the time Jane was six, both of her parents had died and her guardian had seized her father's estate and sent Jane off to school.
Prior to attending the Litchfield Female Academy, she attended the Bethlehem Female Seminary in Bethlehem, PA in 1799. Aftering studying in Litchfield, Jane was hired as a music teacher at the Female Academy from 1810 to 1813. While in Litchfield, Jane developed a relationship with Law School student Charles Greeley Loring.
She was 20 years old when she left America for London to join her brother who had begun suit to claim their legitimate birth right and their father's estate. She wrote a long letter to John Pierce Brace asking him to explain her background to Loring, writing 'I cannot but help thinking that if he knew my situation he would feel differently towards me.' There is no record as to what Brace said to Loring or how Loring reacted, however only a year later Loring became engaged to Brace's sister Anna.
Jane spent the rest of her life teaching and worked in schools in Marietta, OH, Norwalk, CT and kept her own boarding school in Natchez, MI. She died unmarried.
citation_of_attendance:
Letter, Jane E. Shedden to John P. Brace, 20 May 1813 (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy Collection).
Jane E. Shedden is mentioned in Betsy Reynolds 1806-1807 Journal (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy Collection).
additional_notes: Primary sources for Jane E. Shedden include a letter and respective transcript, located in the Litchfield Female Academy collection, Series 2: Student Papers, Records, and Documents, Folder 83.

name: Lucyann Sheffield
biographical_notes: Around the year 1813 Lucyann Sheffield of Derby, Connecticut attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy in Litchfield, Connecticut. No other information is known about Lucyann's life at this time.

name: Charlotte Sheldon
biographical_notes: In 1780 Charlotte Sheldon was born to Dr. Daniel Sheldon of Litchfield, Connecticut. Being a subscriber to Sarah Pierce's Female Academy it is not surprising that in 1796, and again in 1802 Dr. Sheldon had his daughter Charlotte educated at the school. Little else is known about Charlotte's life until her death in 1840.

biographical_notes: In 1811 a student named Huldah Sheldon attended the Litchfield Female Academy. No other information is known about her identity at this time.

name: Lucy Sheldon Beach
biographical_notes: Lucy Sheldon Beach, daughter of Daniel and Huldah Stone Sheldon of Litchfield, Connecticut, was born June 27, 1788. From 1801 until 1803 Lucy was educated at the Litchfield Female Academy. In 1832 she married Theron Beach, a physician, as his second wife. None of their children survived. She inherited her father's house on North Street (now historically called the Sheldon House) and lived there for her entire adult life. Lucy passed away on April 7, 1889 at the age of 100 years.
citation_of_attendance:
Lucy is mentioned as a fellow student in Maryann Bacon's 1802 Journal (Archives, Litchfield Historical Society).
'Beach, Lucy Sheldon (Mrs. Theron) 1802-1803 Journal' (Archives, Litchfield Historical Society).

additional_notes: Journals, an album, and a copy book created by Lucy Sheldon Beach are located in the Litchfield Female Academy collection, Series 2: Student Papers, Records, and Documents, in Folders 3-8.
quotes: 'In her old youth she had not possessed beauty.  In her old age she was handsome, and to the last pleasing to the eye.'  The Hartford Courant, April 9, 1889.

name: Julia Shepard Perkins
biographical_notes: Julia Shepard Perkins, daughter of John Shepard of Athens, Pennsylvania, was born November 11, 1799. As a young girl Julia attended the Pennsylvania Academy in Athens, Pennsylvania, which her father had been a founder of. She then continued her formal educaiton in 1818 in Litchfield, Connecticut where she studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. After a year of studying Julia became an assistant teacher at the the school in 1819. That same year she relocated to the Ithaca Academy, and served as a teacher from 1819 to 1823. Julia later married George A. Perkins, also a native of Athens, Pennsylvania, but little else is known about her life.
citation_of_attendance:
'Catalogue of the Ladies Academy in Litchfield' 1818 by J.A. Shepard (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
Letter, Adaline St. John and Juliana Shepard to Eliza A. Ogden, 11 September 1818 (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy collection).
secondary_sources: Perkins, Mrs. George A. Early Times on the Susquehanna. Binghamton, New York: The Herald Company, 1906.
quotes: 'Were I not as pleasently situated as heart can wish, with the best of friends and associates, and my mind engaged and interested with my literary pursuits, I should be inclined to think I was forgotten. I will hasten to tell you something of Litchfield. It only wants the Tioga and Susquehanna rivers to make it the most delightful place I have ever seen. The society far exceeds the local situation with all its beauty, and there are schools where every science may be studied, charitable institutions for the dissemination of knowledge are established, and every one appears to be engaged in the instruction of the indigent. We have this summer a very interesting school; there are about one hundred pupils.' - Julia Sherpard Perkins (Vanderpoel, Emily Noyes. More Chronicles of A Pioneer School From 1792 to 1833. Cambridge, MA: The University Press, 1927).

name: Lucy Ann Shepard
biographical_notes: Lucy Ann Shepard of Lenox, Massachusetts was baptized around the year 1800. She was the daughter of Samuel and Lucy Ames Shepard. Samuel, an educator and minister, had attended the Litchfield Law School prior to pursing a Doctorate of Divinity at Union College. In 1818 Samuel and his wife sent their daughter Lucy to Litchfield, Connecticut where she studied at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy.
citation_of_attendance: 'Catalogue of the Ladies Academy in Litchfield' 1818 by J.A. Shepard (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Female Academy Collection).

name: Mary Sherman Loomis
biographical_notes: Mary Sherman Loomis was the daughter of Ira and Laura Beach Sherman of Bridgeport, Connecticut. In 1827 Mary received a formal education at the Litchfield Female Academy, and later married James C. Loomis.

biographical_notes: Cornelia Sherrill, daughter of Lewis and Nancy Williams Sherrill of New Hartford, New York, was born October 2, 1809. In 1823 Cornelia attended the Litchfield Female Academy. She passed away four years later on May 4, 1827.
