name: Dr. Charles Wiliam Rogers
biographical_notes:
Charles William Rogers was born in Greenfield Hill, CT, on October 23, 1779, and died in the South on Nov. 24. 1849. He married in Charleston, S. C, Anne West, daughter of Col. Simon Munroe of Sunbury, Georgia, and Elizabeth West. They have five children together.
Charles Rogers was a very wealthy slave and plantation owner, and was noted for his hospitality. He was very fond of high bred horses and was instantly killed upon being hurled against a tree while driving a pair of spirited studs. He was prominent in both South Carolina and Georgia.

name: Commodore Dudley Saltonstall
biographical_notes:
Dudley Saltonstall was born in 1738 to Gurdon Saltonstall Jr and Mary Winthrop. Both sides of his family were prominent in British colonial politics; his great-grandfather on his father's side was Sir Richard Saltonstall, and his mother was descended from John Winthrop, who served as governor of the Province of Massachusetts Bay in the 17th century. His father was a prominent figure in New London and Connecticut politics, serving as a probate judge and a leader of the community. In 1765 he married Frances Babcock, the daughter of Joshua Babcock, a doctor and lawyer who served on the supreme court of the Rhode Island Colony.
Saltonstall took positions on the ships of the colonial mercantile fleet, and served as a merchant captain during the Seven Years' War. In April 1762 he was given command of a letter of marque brigantine, the Britannia, with which he made several successful voyages to the West Indies. During these years he established a reputation as a competent ship's captain.
When the American Revolutionary War broke out, Saltonstall joined Connecticut's militia, helping to defend New London's harbor. When the Continental Navy was established, he was given one of the first captain's commissions, based on the recommendation of his brother-in-law Silas Deane, who served on Connecticut's Naval Committee. He was given command of the Alfred, the flagship of the new navy's commodore, Esek Hopkins. He hired John Paul Jones as his first lieutenant, and gave him the responsibility of overseeing the fitting out of the newly-acquired ship. He and Jones did not get along well, as Jones did not like Saltonstall's sometimes distant and superior demeanor.
Saltonstall captained the Alfred on the Continental Navy's maiden voyage in March 1776, an expedition to Nassau in the Bahamas whose objective was arms and critically needed gunpowder. The expedition was somewhat successful, as Nassau was taken, but its governor had managed to remove much of the gunpowder before the takeover was completed. The return voyage was uneventful, although smallpox was spreading through the ships' crews, until the fleet neared Block Island. On April 4 and 5, the fleet captured British ships. On the morning of April 6, the HMS Glasgow was spotted, and was brought to action. In the ensuing battle, Alfred's steering controls were damaged by cannonfire, and she drifted out of the action. Glasgow was able to escape to Newport outrunning the heavily laden fleet.
While the expedition was successful, Hopkins and Saltonstall were questioned over the fleet's failure to follow its stated orders, which had been to engage the British fleet off the Carolinas, and over its failure to capture the clearly outnumbered Glasgow. Saltonstall was not censured, but other captains in the fleet were punished for cowardly behavior.
In September 1776 Saltonstall was given command of the Trumbull, which had been built at a dockyard on the Connecticut River. To Saltonstall's dismay, she was too heavily laden to cross the sand bar at the mouth of the river. After numerous repeated attempts to pass the bar in 1776 and 1777, the Marine Committee gave her command to Elisha Hinman, who successfully floated her into Long Island Sound in August 1779.
Saltonstall's next command was the Warren, based in Boston. He replaced Hopkins at her helm in July 1779; Hopkins was suspended for breach of orders, and was eventually dismissed from the navy.
In the summer of 1779, the British established a base in Penobscot Bay near present-day Castine, Maine, intended to be the beginning of a new province, New Ireland, and a stronghold for attacking American privateers operating against British shipping.
The state of Massachusetts (which at that time included the District of Maine), organized an expedition to dislodge the British from this position. Saltonstall, the senior Continental Navy commander, was given command of the naval forces, which consisted primarily of ships from the Massachusetts State Navy, a large number of privateers, and a few Continental Navy ships, include the Warren. Command of the land forces accompanying the expedition was given to a relatively inexperienced Massachusetts militia brigadier general, Solomon Lovell.
The unwieldy fleet had virtually no captains with experience in any sort of fleet operations, and many of them were used to the independence afforded by their privateering operations. While Saltonstall had participated in the Nassau expedition, he had only exercised command over his ship. Furthermore, the expedition was to be his maiden voyage aboard his new command. The expedition sailed for Penobscot Bay on July 19. When it arrived near the British base, commanders of the various forces met to consider their attack in a council that was later described by Paul Revere, the militia's artillery leader, as 'more like a meeting in a Coffee House than a council of War'.[1] Nothing of consequence was agreed, and the resultant lack of coordination between the various forces proved disastrous. Saltonstall and Lovell disagreed on tactics, and Saltonstall refused to take steps to engage the three British ships that were anchored near the fort in somewhat treacherous waters. He finally engaged Henry Mowat's small fleet at long range on June 29; his inexperienced gunnery crews did little damage, while Mowat's did significant damage to Warren and other ships. This made Saltonstall reluctant to order further engagements, including in support of land and amphibious operations. The arrival of a British relief fleet under Admiral George Collier at the mouth of the bay led to further strains. Saltonstall at first set up a line of defense against the arriving fleet, but when they began to close, he essentially ordered each ship to act independently, and the fleet organization dissolved. Most of the ships were eventually grounded and burned; some were captured after brief exchanges by the British. The land forces were essentially abandoned, and many men had to make lengthy overland treks back to civilization.
Saltonstall's reported inaction and timidity were blamed for the failure of the expedition. Saltonstall was court-martialed in September 1779, found guilty, and eventually dismissed from military service
Saltonstall returned to Connecticut, and convinced one of his wife's relatives, Adam Babcock, to support him in a privateering venture. As captain of the 16-gun brig Minerva, he embarked on a successful career as a privateer in 1781. Among his prizes was the richest captured by a Connecticut ship; the British ship Hannah was valued at £80,000.
After the war, he engaged in trade with the West Indies, and also dabbled in the slave trade. He died in 1796 in the West Indies,apparently of a tropical disease.

name: Molly Marsh Seymour
biographical_notes: Molly was the daughter of Col. Ebenezer and Deborah (Buell) Marsh of Litchfield. She married Moses Seymour in 1771 and they had six children.

name: Ozias Seymour
biographical_notes: Ozias, a son of Maj. Moses Seymour, was born in Litchfield in 1776 and died there in 1851. He was a pioneer manufacturer of hats, ran a farm, and served as deputy and later sheriff of Litchfield county from 1819 to 1834. He married Selima Storrs (1786-1814), a daughter of Dan Storrs and Ruth Conant Storrs of Mansfield, Conn. Ozias Seymour and Selima Storrs Seymour had four children: Origen Storrs Seymour (1804-1881), Henrietta Sophronia Seymour Woodruff (1806-1892), Amelia Seymour Sanford (1809-1833), and Maria Seymour Sanford (1813-1836).

name: Moses Simons
biographical_notes: Father of Litchfield Law School student Moses Aaron Simons. Emigrated from London to the US between 1772-1783 along with his father Isaac Simons and four brothers, settling in South Carolina.
secondary_sources: Copland, Laura. 'The Rise and Fall of Moses Simons: A Black Lawyer in the New York	City Criminal Court, 1816-1820.' African Americans in New York Life and	History 37.2 (2013): 81-114.

name: Adaline Hatch Bennett
biographical_notes: Adaline Hatch was one of ten children of Reuben Hatch and Eunice Dennison Hatch.  Her father migrated to Norwich, Vermont from Preston, Connecticut as a child.  He was a member of the General Assembly of that state and a candidate for town representative from Norwich.  She married Milo L. Bennett.

name: David Whittlesey (1787-1869)
biographical_notes: David Whittlesey was born in New Preston, CT on August 18, 1787. His first marriage to Patience Averill resulted in six children. After the death of his first wife, David was remarried to Annie Tryon-Taylor, and the couple had two children. On March 20, 1869 David Whittlesey passed away.
additional_notes: David Whittlesey is buried in the New Preston Village Cemetery in New Preston, CT.

name: Henry Seymour (1780-1837)
state_committees: President of the Farmers' Loan & Trust Company of the city of New York
biographical_notes: Henry Seymour held important public offices in the state of New York, including the offices of State Senator, Canal Commissioner, and Mayor of Utica. Prior to his death, his last held office was that of the President of the Farmers' Loan & Trust Company of New York.   On the morning of August 26, 1837 when Henry was fifty-six years old, he committed suicide by shooting himself at half past 8 o'clock in the morning.
quotes: 'For several weeks previous it had been observed by his family and some of his friends that he was partially derranged, and his singular conduct had excited their apprehensions.  The usual strength and soundness of his intellect, and the calmness of mind and decission of character for which he was conspicuous, had been palpably impaired; and, althouhg occassionally subject during his life to a depression of spirits, arising from bodily infirmities, he was perceived lately to be more than ever a sufferer from hypochondria.'  Utica Observer, August 30, 1837.

name: Aaron Ogden
biographical_notes: Aaron Ogden was born and raised in Elizabethtown (now Elizabeth), New Jersey. He graduated from the College of New Jersey (now Princeton University) in 1773. During the American Revolution, he served as an officer in the military, rising to brigade major. He also studied law and was admitted to the bar in 1784.    He later practiced law in his hometown even as he turned to politics. He served as presidential elector in 1796, as clerk of Essex County from 1785 to 1803, and was elected on the Federalist ticket to the United States Senate in 1801 after the serving New Jersey representative resigned. He ran unsuccessfully for re-election in 1802 and left the Senate in 1803.    In 1812, Ogden was elected as the eighth Governor of New Jersey and the next year turned down an offer from President James Madison to serve as a major general in the U.S. Army. After an unsuccessful re-election campaign, Ogden retired from politics and concentrated in stead on his legal career.    At this time, he became interested in and involved with the steamboat business. Indeed, he became embroiled in a landmark Supreme Court case in 1824. The state of New York had granted Ogden a monopoly on steamboat ferries between New Jersey and New York on the Hudson River. Another ferry, owned by a man named Gibbons, operated on this same route (he claimed the federal government had given him a monopoly) and Ogden sought an injunction against him. Eventually, Chief Justice John Marshall ruled in favor of Gibbons, finding that New York's monopoly was in violation of the Constitution which says, 'Congress shall have the power to regulate commerce ... among the several States.' This landmark case rapidly expanded the control Congress had over commercial activities and enabled it rapid growth in power throughout the next century. Marshall, a Federalist, believed that industry and commerce were the best path for the financial stability and growth of the United States.    Aaron Ogden married Elizabeth Chetwood. The couple had seven children, including Law School student Matthias Ogden and Female Academy student Amelia Ogden. Other children include Mary Chetwood Ogden, Phebe Ann Ogden, John Ogden, Elias B. D. Ogden, and two that died as small children.    Ogden died in April, 1839 and is interred in the First Presbyterian Church Burial Ground in Elizabeth, New Jersey.
secondary_sources: Biographical Directory of the United States Congress. 'OGDEN, Aaron (1756 - 1839).' http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=o000041 National Governors Association. 'New Jersey Governor Aaron Ogden.' http://www.nga.org/cms/home/governors/past-governors-bios/page_new_jersey/col2-content/main-content-list/title_ogden_aaron.html McBride, Alex. 'Landmark Cases: Gibbons v. Ogden (1824).' PBS: Supreme Court History. http://www.pbs.org/wnet/supremecourt/antebellum/landmark_gibbons.html
private_notes: Images of him do exist in the world. But I don't know if we can use them or not because I just don't know about these things. -- BK 5/11/4
government_posts: Federal/U.S. Senator//New Jersey;State/Governor//New Jersey

name: Truman Marsh
biographical_notes:
Truman Marsh was born in Litchfield, Connecticut, on February 24, 1768. After completing his education in the common schools he was prepared for college by the Rev. George Beckwith, the Congregational minister of Litchfield South Farms. He then entered into his studies at Yale College, and graduated in 1786.
After graduation Mr. Marsh went to Maryland and became a tutor and instructor at Cokesbury College near Baltimore, under the Rev. Levi Heath who gave him a full theological course of study at the same time. After his ordination Mr. Marsh also began assisting Mr. Heath in the parochial work of St. John’s parish in Baltimore. He desired to become a clergyman in his native state however, and when the parish of St. John’s in New Milford, Connecticut became vacant he gladly accepted the invitation in 1790 to become its rector.
In 1799 Mr. Marsh left St. John’s to replace the Rev. David Butler at St. Michael’s in Litchfield. It was there that he spent the remainder of his life. When his health and endurance began to fail after 1810 he continued his work with assistants (among them were the Rev. Dr. Isaac Jones, the Rev. Dr. John S. Stone, and the Rev. William Lucas) until his resignation in 1830. After retiring as rector of St. Michael’s he remained in Litchfield to be the confidant and adviser to many of his former parishioners, the counselor and friends of his successors in the parish, and a respected senior among his brethren of the clergy.

name: John Breckinridge
biographical_notes: Breckenridge was a Senator from Kentucky; born near Staunton, Augusta County, Va., December 2, 1760; educated at Augusta Academy, near Staunton (now Washington and Lee University, Lexington, Va.), and at William and Mary College, Williamsburg, Va.; elected a member of the house of burgesses in 1780 when nineteen years of age, but being under age was not allowed to take his seat until elected the third time; served as subaltern in the Virginia Militia during the Revolutionary War; studied law; admitted to the bar in 1785 and commenced practice in Charlottesville, Va.; elected as a Democrat to the Third Congress, but resigned in 1792 before the commencement of the congressional term; moved to Kentucky in 1793 and resumed the practice of law in Lexington; unsuccessful candidate for election to the United States Senate in 1794; appointed attorney general of Kentucky in 1795 and served until November 30, 1797, when he resigned; member, State house of representatives 1798-1800, serving as speaker in 1799 and 1800; member of the State constitutional convention in 1799; elected as a Democratic Republican to the United States Senate and served from March 4, 1801, until August 7, 1805, when he resigned to accept the position of Attorney General of the United States in the Cabinet of President Thomas Jefferson; served in this capacity until his death at ‘Cabell’s Dale,’ near Lexington, Ky., December 14, 1806; interment in Lexington Cemetery, Lexington, Ky.
secondary_sources: Biographical Directory of the United States Congress http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=b000787 accessed April 7, 2011.

name: Nancy Bradley Mulford (1778-1841)
biographical_notes: Nancy Bradley Mulford, born in 1778, had a long relationship with the educational institutuions of Litchfield Connecticut. Her father, Abraham Bradley, had studied law in Litchfield at Tapping Reeve's law school. It is believed that prior to 1809 Nancy may have also been sent to Litchfield, Connecticut to receive a formal education at Sarah Pierce's Female Academy. In her later life she and her husband Henry sent their daughters Eliza and Nancy to study at Sarah Pierce's school as well.

name: Susan M.C.
biographical_notes: Susan M.C. may have been a student at the Litchfield Female Academy sometime between 1830 and 1832. A collection of papers relating to her are housed at the Connecticut Historical Society. These papers seem likely to have been received from other young women while studying in Litchfield.

name: Mary Norton Cowles
biographical_notes: Mary Norton Cowles of Farmington, Connecticut may have attended the Litchfield Female Academy around the year 1831. Mary wrote a poem to Susan M.C. (another possible student of the female academy).

name: Laura Huesley
biographical_notes: Laura Huesley of Norfolk, Connecticut may have attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1830. She wrote a poem to Susan M.C. (a possible Female Academy student) that year.

name: Mary Fay Robinson
biographical_notes: Mary Fay Robinson is currently an unconfirmed student. Her only link to the Litchfield Female Academy are the two ink on silk mouning pictures and one silk embroidery picture she completed in her youth. While there is not yet a strong artistic link between the pictures she completed and other works done by the Litchfield Female Academy, they do indicate she attended a girls school.
additional_notes: The Bennington Museum in Bennington, VT also includes a silhouette and oil painting of Mary Fay Robinson later in her life.

name: Frances Perkins
biographical_notes: Frances Perkins is believed to have attended the Litchfield Female Academy in 1800. A silk embroidery picture attributed to her survives in a private collection however she does not appear in any existing Female Academy records. Her brother Charles Perkins attended the Litchfield Law School but her sister Harriet attended an academy in Norwich, CT.

name: Louise Clark Camp
biographical_notes: Louise Clark Camp was born to Deacon Merritt Clark and his wife Lydia Kellogg in Northfield, CT. She married Ralph Garwood Camp and had one son, Arthur Kellogg Camp, in 1846. She died in 1848.
secondary_sources: Clark, Albert, Family records of George Clark and Daniel Kellogg : with their descendants, also family record in part of Edward NashWashington, D.C. : A.C. Patterson, 1877. Hopkins, Timothy, The Kelloggs in the Old world and the New, Volume 1 Sunset press and photo engraving co., 1903.

name: Henry Middleton (1770-1846)
biographical_notes:
Henry Middleton was born in London, England on September 28, 1770. His parents, then traveling in Europe, returned a year later to South Carolina. Henry pursued classical studies with tutors at his father’s estate, Middleton Place, near Charleston, S.C. (which is today a historic house museum), and spent a year in England.
He returned to America after his father’s death in 1787 but briefly returned to England and resided at Clifton, Gloucestershire, until his return to Charleston in 1800. At that point, Henry engaged in planting in South Carolina and entered politics.
He was a member of the South Carolina State house of representatives from 1802 to 1810 and then elected to the State senate in 1810. Henry became Governor of South Carolina in December 1810 and served until December 1812. Later he was elected as a Republican to the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Congresses (March 4, 1815-March 3, 1819) and was an unsuccessful candidate for renomination in 1818.
From 1820 to 1830 he served as teh Minister to Russia. Henry was the leader of the Union Party of South Carolina and vice president of the Union Convention in 1833. At this point he retired from public life and died in Charleston, S.C. on June 14, 1846. He is buried in the family mausoleum at “Middleton Place,” near Charleston, S.C.
government_posts: Federal/U.S. Representative//South Carolina;Federal/Diplomatic Agent//Minister to Russia;State/State House of Representatives//South Carolina;State/State Senator//South Carolina

name: Stephen Mix Mitchell (1743-1835)
biographical_notes: Stephen Mix Mitchell was born at Wethersfield, December 20th, 1743; educated at Yale College, and graduated in 1763; studied law at New-Haven, while a Tutor in Yale-College, and afterwards, under the direction of Jared Ingersoll, Esq.; admitted to the bar, in Fairfield County, in 1770; removed to Wethersfield, in 1772, and established himself in the practice of the law. In May 1779, he accepted the office of an associate Judge of the County Court, and relinquished practice; held that office until May 1790, when he was placed at the head of that Court; held the latter situation, until October 1795, when he was appointed a Judge of the Superior Court; and in May 1807, Chief Justice of that Court; which office he held until May 1814, when he became legally disqualified by age.    He represented the town of Wethersfield in the General Assembly of this state, in Oct. 1778, May 1779, Oct. 1779, May 1780, Oct. 1780, May 1781, Oct. 1781, May 1782, Oct. 1782, (when he was chosen Clerk of the House of Reps.) May 1783, and Oct. 1783. He was chosen Assistant in May 1784, and annually thereafter, for nine successive years; and was, in that capacity, a member of the Supreme Court of Errors.    He was a delegate from this State in Congress of the United States previous to the adoption of the Constitution, in the years 1783, 1785, 1786, 1787, and 1788. In Oct. 1793, he was appointed a Senator from this State in the Congress of the United States, for the unexpired part of the term made vacant by the death of the Hon. Roger Sherman; in which situation he continued until he became a Judge of the Superior Court, in October 1795.    In September 1807, he received from the Corporation of Yale College the honorary degree of LL. D. He was a member of the Convention that formed the Constitution of this State in 1818. He died at his residence in Wethersfield, Sept. 30th, 1835.

name: Charles Lucas
admitted_to_bar: 1814 admitted to the Missouri Territory bar
biographical_notes:
Charles Lucas was the son of John B.C. Lucas and Anne (Sebin) Lucas. He was born in Pittsburgh, PA but his father soon relocated the family to St. Louis, MO. In 1806, Charles was sent east to Philadelphia for schooling. After he completed his education, he attended the Litchfield Law School.
Lucas returned to St. Louis in 1811 and joined a territorial militia unit sent to patrol along the Illinois River. He subsequently transferred to a St. Louis volunteer artillery company led by his brother Robert. When Robert resigned his command in 1813, the St. Louis volunteers elected Charles to replace him. He was given the rank of Captain and for the duration of the War of 1812, the artillery company he commanded periodically reported for duty at the nearby military installation at Portage des Sioux.
In 1814, Lucas was admitted to the territorial bar and that same year he won a seat in the territorial assembly as a representative from St. Louis County. Three years later President James Madison appointed him U.S. Attorney for the Missouri Territory. Lucas dabbled in land speculation and in 1816 he and Asa Morgan purchased a tract of land in present day Cooper County that they had chosen for a new town. They drew up plans and laid out a plat for Boonville, Missouri which they filed in 1817.
The popular and well liked young Lucas soon found himself at odds with Thomas Hart Benton, another rising member of the St. Louis bar. Benton had allied himself with a political faction highly critical of Lucas' father who had become a staunch foe of the territory's Spanish land claimants. Charles Lucas and Benton first clashed publicly while representing opposing parties in a case argued in the St. Louis Circuit Court in October 1816. They exchanged insults in their closing statements and after losing the case Benton alleged that Lucas had defamed him. He demanded satisfaction in a duel but Lucas declined the challenge.
Their paths crossed again on election day in August 1817 when Lucas questioned Benton's eligibility to vote on grounds that he had failed to pay his taxes. Benton's derisive dismissal of his detractor as a 'puppy' provoked Lucas to respond by demanding to settle the affront with a duel. Benton accepted, and they faced off on Bloody Island near St. Louis on August 12 using smoothbore pistols at a distance of thirty feet. Benton escaped from the encounter with a bruised knee but Lucas sustained more serious injuries from a bullet that cut an artery in his neck.
Initially both men pronounced themselves satisfied. Benton subsequently reconsidered and demanded a second meeting after declaring that Lucas' friends had questioned his conduct in the affair. Their second meeting took place on September 27, 1817, and in that encounter Lucas died after a bullet hit near his heart.
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]
secondary_sources: Christensen, William O. ed. Dictionary of Missouri Biography. Columbia, MO: University of Missouri Press, 1999.
government_posts: Federal/U.S. Attorney//Missouri Territory

name: Samuel Wolcott
biographical_notes: Claimed to have been with his father at the capture of Fort Ticonderoga during the American Revolution.  He married Isabella Blair from Worcester, Massachusetts. Samuel was one a dozen pioneers in the settlement of Shoreham, Vermont. These men cleared and conditioned their jointly purchased land. They also lived in a cabin together and shared the daily chores. They were driven out by Indians but returned after the American Revolution.

name: Harriet Pratt
biographical_notes: Harriet Pratt of Cornwall, Connecticut is believed to have attended Sarah Pierce's Female Academy around the year 1812. While studying in Litchfield Harriet created a map of the United States similar to others produced at the Pierce school.
citation_of_attendance: Map of the Untied States by Harriet Pratt (Cornwall Historical Society).
materials: Map of the United States by Harriet Pratt

name: Margaret Connor Frisbie
biographical_notes: Margaret Connor Frisbie was born around the year 1801 in Kentucky to William and Anna Connor. On February 15, 1818 she married William Carter in Perry County, Indiana. After William's death Margaret was remarried to Samuel Frisbie on April 6, 1825 in Perry County, Indiana. During their marriage the couple had eight children. On December 27, 1876 Margaret passed away.
additional_notes: Margaret Connor Fribie's Gravestone reads: 'IN MEMORY OF MARGARET/ Wife of SAMUEL FRISBIE/ DIED Dec 27 1876/ Ages About 75 years'.

name: David Dudley Field (1805-1894)
biographical_notes: David Dudley Field was the eldest child of the Rev. David Dudley Field, pastor of the Congregational Church in Stockbridge. Born in 1805, the younger Field began his legal studies in 1825 in Stockbridge. He then continued his legal studies in Albany, and finally in New York City. On October 26, 1829 he married Lucinda Hopkins Field in Stockbridge. After their marriage the couple reisded in New York City, where they had their three children. Lucinda passed away on January 1, 1836. David Dudley Field went on to become one of the leading trial and appellate lawyers in New York and before the U.S. Supreme Court, and one of the most important law reformers in American history. He married twice again after his first wife's death, and all of his wives predeceased him. He died in New York on April 19, 1894.

name: Edward Dunham
biographical_notes: Edward Dunham was born March 27, 1819 in New Brunswick, New Jersey. On January 27, 1848 he was married to Minerva Warner Harrison of Litchfield, Connecticut. In March of the following year his wife gave birth to their daughter, Clarinda Harrison. Two years later Minerva passed away. On March 29, 1855 Edward was remarried to Penelope Butler Parker of Perth Amboy, New Jersey. Edward passed away in 1892 in New Jersey.

name: William Edmund Dickinson
biographical_notes: William Edmund Dickinson was the son of William and Mary Ann Wright Walker of New York. After his parent's death, he and his sister Mary Ann were adopted by family friends Anson Dickinson and Sarah Brown. During his life William married four times. He had eight children with his fourth wife, Elizabeth Sargent Dickinson. William passed away on June 15, 1899 in Florence, Wisconsin.
additional_notes: William is buried at Aurora, Florence, Wisconsin, Commonwealth Cemetery.

name: William Coombs Thompson
biographical_notes: William Coombs Thompson was born March 17, 1802 in Salisbury, New Hampshire. In 1820 he graduated from Dartmouth College. After completing his studies there he pursued a education in law. At this time Thompson may have attended the Litchfield Law School in Litchfield, Connecticut before studying with George Blake in Boston, Massachusetts and with Parker Noyes of Salisbury, New Hampshire. In 1824 he opened a law office in Concord, and remained there two years. From 1828 through 1852 he lived and practices law in Plymouth, New Hampshire before removing to Worcester, Massachusetts where he lived the remainder of his life. Thompson married twice during his lifetime. First to Martha Levertt Thompson on October 15, 1828. After Marth'a death he married Susan Nelson Thompson. William Coombs Thompson passed away on April 27, 1877.
secondary_sources:
Charles H. Bell. The Bench and Bar of New Hampshire. Boston: Houghton, Mifflin and Company, 1894.
George T. Chapman. Sketches of the Alumni of Dartmouth College. Cambridge: Printed at the Riverside Press, 1867.
additional_notes: No primary source citation for William Coombs Thompson's attendance at the Litchfield Law School has been found at this time. Until one is located he will be considred a possible student.

name: John Van Deusen Reed
biographical_notes: John Van Deusen Reed, son of Helen Van Deusen Reed and Almet Reed, was born April 26, 1838 in New York. He married Marie Louise Mitchell of New York, and together the couple had three children. John passed away on January 26, 1892 in Paris, France. His wife passed away two months later.

name: Marie Mitchell Reed
biographical_notes: Marie Mitchell Reed was born November 24, 1840 in New York. He was married to John Van Deusen Reed, and together the couple had three children. Marie passed away in Paris, France on March 14, 1892, two months after her husband's passing.

name: Abby Hewes Kingsbury
biographical_notes: Abby Hewes Kingsbury, daughter of Daniel and Abigail Shepard Huewes, was born in 1804. She was married to John Southmayd Kingsbury, and during their marriage the couple had eight children. Abby passed away in 1898.

name: Lydia Smith Russell
biographical_notes: Lydia and Jonathan were married in Boston, MA.
additional_notes: Lydia Smith Russell passed away in Milton, MA.

name: Jonathan Russell, Jr.
biographical_notes: Jonathan and Lydia were married in Boston, MA.
additional_notes: Jonathan passed away in Milton, MA.

name: Huntington Wolcott Freeman
biographical_notes: Huntington Wolcott Freeman was the son of Hannah Huntington Wolcott Freeman of Litchfield, CT and the Rev. Frederick Freeman of Sandwich, MA. They were married on April 21, 1834. Hannah Freeman died on February 26, 1838 in Manayunk, PA, possibly from the effects of childbirth. Her infant daughter dies 4 months later.
private_notes: Hannah Huntington Wolcott Freeman's Brides Album (2012-6-0) was donated along with a Portrait of a Young Woman (2012-6-1). This is not a portrait of Hannah as it was painted much later, after her death.

name: Sarah Watkins Gould
biographical_notes: Sarah and Robert married in London and had seven children.

name: Sarah Davis Gould
biographical_notes: Sarah and Robert had two children.

name: Elizabeth Page Gould
biographical_notes: Elizabeth Page Gould was Robert Howe Gould's third wife. Together they had three children. She was widowed in their home in Nelson, New Zealand, in 1888.

name: Cornelia Curtiss Deming
biographical_notes: Cornelia Curtiss Deming was the daughter of Peter and Eliza Wadsworth Curtiss. Cornelia was married to Frederic Deming of Farmington, Connecticut, and during her lifetime established a successful catering business. After Cornelia's death the business was managed by her daughter, Gertrude Deming Biesenthal. The business remained in operation into World War II.

name: Julia Gould Hunter
biographical_notes: Julia Gould Hunter was born in 1829 to William Tracy Gould and his wife Anna McKinne Gould. One of three children to be born during the marriage, Julia was raised in Augusta, Georgia. On November 5, 1850 she was wed to William Hunter in Richmond, Georgia.

name: Mary Barger Jones
biographical_notes: Mary Barger Jones was born in Pennsylvania on May 17, 1767. On February 11, 1791 she married John Rice Jones in the town of Vincennes in the Northwest Territory (later Indiana Territory and currently the state of Indiana). During their thirty-three year marriage the couple had eight children. Around 1808 the Jones family relocated to Kaskasia, the seat of government of the newly formed Illinois Territory. Two year later they moved to St. Genevieve in the Louisiana Territory, then headed to St. Louis, and finally settled in Mine a Breton in the Louisiana Territory (later to be incorporated as the town of Potosi in the Missouri Territory). It was in Potosi that Mary Barger Jones spent in last year of her life. She died there on January 6, 1839.
residences: Vincennes/Northwest Territory/United States;Kaskaskia/Illinois Territory/United States;St. Genevieve/Louisiana Territory/;St. Louis/Louisiana Territory/;Mine a Breton/Louisiana Territory/;Potosi/Missouri Territory/

name: Samuel Adams (1706-1788)
biographical_notes: Samuel Adams, born May 3, 1706, was a native of New Milford, Connecticut. Early in his life he relocated to Stratford, Connecticut, where he made a career as a lawyer and judge of the Fairfield County Court. On March 7, 1728 he married Mary Fairchild/ A few years before his death he removed to Litchfield adn assisted his son, the Honorable Andrew Adams, in his extensive law practice. Samuel Adams passed away in Litchfield on November 12, 1788.

name: Mary Fairchild Adams (1698-1803)
biographical_notes: Mary Fairchild Adams was born May 7, 1698. On March 7, 1728 he wed Samuel Adams, a lawyer and judge in Stratford, Connecticut. The couple later moved to Litchfield, Connecticut, where Samuel assisted his son Andrew with his extensive legal practice. Mary Fairchild Adams passed away in Litchfield on August 29, 1803 at the age of 105.
private_notes: The Ledger will not accept an 18th century date as a 'correct format', which is why her birth date is not entered into the 'Born' line above.

name: Walter Dean Smith
biographical_notes: Walter Dean Smith, son of Ebenezer and Sarah Dean Smith, was born in New Marlboro, Massachusetts on October 12, 1773. Walter, a lawyer by profession, married his second wife, Hetty Bull Hosford in September 1806. The couple had two children, a daughter and son. Walter Dean Smith passed away on March 15, 1852.

name: Hetty Bull Hosford Smith
biographical_notes: Hetty Bull Hosford, daughter of Amos and Esther Bull Hosford, of Berlin, Connecticut was born November 24, 1786. In September of 1806 she married Walter Dean Smith, Esq., of Hartford, Connecticut. The couple had two children during their marriage, a daughter and a son. Hetty Bull Hosford Smith passed away on June 3, 1856.

name: Andrew Hosford Smith
biographical_notes: Andrew Hosford Smith was born in Berlin, Connecticut on May 30, 1812. His parents were Walter Dean and Hetty Bull Hosford Smith. Andrew spent the early years of his boyhood on a farm, and, when ten years of age, went to Hartford, Connecticut with his parents, and was there educated in the public schools.

name: Simeon Parsons Smith
biographical_notes: Simeon Parsons Smith was born July 31, 1809. On January 27, 1833 he married Hetty Hosford Smith of Hartford, Connecticut, and the couple had one child. After Hetty's death in 1840, Simeon married Eliza VanNess Lyle. He passed away in Baltimore, Maryland on Feburary 6, 1848.

name: Roger Newton Whittlesey
biographical_notes: Roger Newton Whittlesey, son of Rev. Samuel and Susannah Newton Whittlesey, was born in New Milford, CT on February 24, 1754. Roger was a farmer, and for a time a Justice of the Peace for Litchfield County. He also served as a soldier during the Revolutionary War. On April 20, 1775 he married Ann Woodruff, and the couple had thirteen children during their marriage. Roger passed away on March 15, 1835.
government_posts: Local/Justice of the Peace//Litchfield County, CT

name: Ann Woodruff Whittlesey
biographical_notes: Ann Woodruff Whittlesey was born April 5, 1756 to Jacob and Anne Griswold Woodruff of Litchfield, Connecticut. On April 20, 1775 she wed Roger Newton Whittlesey, a farmer originally from New Milford. During their marriage Ann and Roger had thirteen children. Ann passed away on March 7, 1825.

name: Susannah Newton Whittlesey Hamlin
biographical_notes: Susannah Newton Whittlesey Hamlin was first married to Samuel Whittlesey. The couple had at least one son together, Roger Newton Whittlesey. After Samuel's death, Susannah married Jabez Hamlin.

name: Cornelius Dubois (1810-1882)
biographical_notes: Cornelius Dubois was the son of the successful merchant and tobacco agent Cornelius Dubois and his wife Sarah Platt Ogden. Dubois was one of five children and received his early education at Louis Baucel's French Boarding School. He graduated from Columbia in 1828 and after attending the Litchfield Law School in 1830 and after being admitted to the bar in New York City in 1833, he became the partner of Edgar Van Winkle for four years. Due to his father's desire for him to join his tobacco agency so he could soon retire, Dubois gave up his legal practice in 1836 and joined his father's mercantile firm. When his father retired in 1840, he and his father's business partner, Issac A. Storm formed a new partnership. Dubois would later take a new partner and the firm became knowns as Dubois and Vandervoot.     He met his wife Mary Ann Delafied, the sister of of fellow Law School student John Delafield, in New York City and they took the stage back to Litchfield together. They married in 1832 and had 10 children. For over 30 years, they resided at 80 Gramercy Park in New York City. Dubois died in New York City and is buried in Marble Cemetery.
citation_of_attendance: Letter, 28 October 1830, Cornelius DuBois to Edgar Van Winkle (Litchfield Historical Society - Litchfield Law School Collection).
quotes: On October 28, 1830 wrote to to Edgar Van Winkle about 'an exhibition of the young ladies' Seminary in this place' where 'there were several very handsome and interesting young demoiselles.'     'I understand from Mrs. Reeves that all the marriageable young ladies have been married off, and that there is at present nothing but young fry in town, consequently that it will not be as gay as usual. The young ladies, she tells me, all marry law students, but it will take two or three years for the young crop to become fit for the harvest, you need apprehend no danger of my throwing up my bachlorship [sic].'

name: Cornelius Dubois (1771-1846)
biographical_notes: Cornelius Dubois was the son of Peter Dubois and Maria VanVorhees, but was reared by his stepfather, Dr. Theodorus VanWyck. Cornelius was a wholesale grocer with Kip & Dubois, a tobacco importer, and a cigar maker.

name: Sarah Platt Ogden Dubois
biographical_notes: Daughter of Robert Ogden and Sarah Platt.

name: Samuel Ames
other_education: Attended Phillips Academy in 1819, and received a degree from Brown University in 1823.
state_committees: Speaker of the State House of Representatives in 1844 and 1845. RI Representative to the 1865 Peace Conference in Washington, D.C.
biographical_notes: Samuel Ames was the eldest son of Samuel and Anne Checkley Ames. He studied at Phillips Academy in Andover, Massachusetts in 1819 and graduated from Brown University in 1823. He then attended the Litchfield Law School in 1824. After he was admitted to the Rhode Island Bar in 1826, Ames opened a law office in Providence, Rhode Island, and in 1839 married Mary Door of Providence. In 1832 he assisted Joseph K. Angell in the preparation of his treatise on 'Corporation Law'. He served as quartermaster general for the state troops during the Dorr Rebellion (led by his wife's brother Thomas Wilson Dorr). Ames also played an active role in Rhode Island politics and not only served as a City Council member in Providence, but also served as a state representative in the Rhode Island General Assembly.
citation_of_attendance: Catalogue of the Litchfield Law School (Hartford, CT: Press of Case, Tiffany and Company, 1848), 20.
secondary_sources: Lewis, William Draper. Great American Lawyers, Vol. 5. Philadelphia: The John C. Winston Company, 1908.     Payne, Abraham. Reminiscences of the Rhode Island Bar. Providence, RI: Tibbitts and Preston, 1885.
additional_notes: He was the co-author of Reports of Cases Argued and Determined in the Supreme Court of Rhode Island, 1828-1887, and was the author of Rhode Island Rebellion, 1842 Extracts from Newspapers; Robert H. Ives vs. Charles T. Hazard (and others) Opening argument for Complainant
government_posts: State/State Representative//Rhode Island;State/Chief Justice/of the Supreme Court/Rhode Island;Local/City Council//Providence, RI

name: Thomas Smith Webb Mott
biographical_notes: Thomas Smith Webb Mott was born in Preston, Nova Scotia on July 28, 1800 to John Mott, a farmer, and his wife, Deborah Webb, who was originally from Massachusetts. In 1822 he attended Brown University, and after the completion of his degree was ordained as an Episcopalian minister. He was the first editor of the Episcopalian Newspaper 'The Church Intelligencer.' He served parishes in Massachusetts, Georgia, Mississippi and then relocated to North Carolina where he had a long and successful career. In addition, he established and taught at several schools, including St. Johns in the Wilderness in Flatrock, NC. On June 29, 1833 he was married to Susan Amanda Phillips. The couple had at least three sons during their marriage, all of which pursued medical careers.

name: Rosa Stiles Caperton
additional_notes: Rosa was first married to R.H. Christian. Her second marriage was to William Gaston Caperton.

name: Josephine Clifford Stiles
biographical_notes: Josephine Clifford Stiles was the daughter of Litchfield Law School student Joseph Clay Stiles. Josephine took on the task of teaching her brother Eugene's children in their early years. Later most of the children were taken in by Stiles relatives in Connecticut, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania and received additional education.
additional_notes: Josephine Clifford Stiles is buried in Hollywood Cemetery in Richmond, VA.

name: Robert Augustus Stiles
additional_notes: Robert Augustus Stiles is buried in Hollywood Cemetery in Richmond, VA.

name: Randolph Riley Stiles
biographical_notes: Randolph Riley Stiles is the son of Litchfield Law School student Joseph Clay Stiles.
additional_notes: Randolph Riley Stiles fell to his death from a waterfall near Shawsville, VA and is buried in Hollywood Cemetery in Richmond, VA.

name: Eugene West Stiles
biographical_notes: Eugene West Stiles was the son of Joseph Clay Stiles, a student of the Litchfield Law School in 1817. Stiles was married twice during his lifetime. His first wife was Caroline B. Anderson of Shawsville, Virginia. Stiles' second wife was Rosabel Bolling of Montgomery County ,Virginia. Following his second marriage Eugene acquired a farm in Seneca Hollow, Virginia. Throughout his life he served as a minister and also worked as a farmer, and had nine children (one from his first marriage, and eight from his second). He was a veteran of the Confederate Army and attended the 50th reunion at Gettysburg. He and his wife Rosabel are buried in Sunset cemetery in Christansburg, Virginia.

name: Robert Woodruff Condit
biographical_notes: Reverend Robert Woodruff Condit was born September 9, 1795 and died February 11, 1871. In 1820 he married Harriet Whittlesey Condit, a student of the Litchfield Female Academy.
additional_notes: Robert was the cousin of Litchfield Law School student Jacob A. Condit.

name: Caleb Hopkins
biographical_notes: Caleb Hopkins was born in Truro, Massachusetts on January 2, 1780. He later moved to Catskill, New York where he married Keturah (Hill). They had 9 children. He died October 23, 1852.

name: Keturah Hill Hopkins
biographical_notes: Keturah Hill Hopkins was born to Hyland Hill and Keturah (Waterhouse) in 1789 in Catskill, New York. She married Caleb Hopkins and they had 9 children. She died January 19, 1878.

name: Abel Brace
other_education: Studied medicine with Dr. Thomas O'Hara Croswell in Catskill, NY.
biographical_notes: Abel Brace was born in Litchfield, Connecticut on October 7, 1794 to James and Susan Pierce Brace. Abel was the second of five children, and the second son to be born into the family. Two years prior to his birth, Abel's aunt, Sarah Pierce, founded the Litchfield Female Academy. His older brother, John Pierce Brace would later play a pivotal role in assisting in the education of countless numbers of students at that school.     At a young age, Abel traveled to Catskill, New York where he studied medicine with his uncle Dr. Thomas O'Hara Croswell, the first physician in Catskill. After completing his studies with Dr. Croswell, Abel began practicing medicine in Catskill as well, and continued in that profession for the remainder of his life. In addition to his personal practice, by the late 1820s he and Dr. Croswell were operating a drug store in Catskill together as well (Dr. Croswell had opened the drug store around the year 1795).     On April 18, 1817 at the age of twenty-two Abel was married for a second time to Betsey Doane with whom he had at least seven children. On October 23, 1863 Abel passed away in Catskill.
additional_notes: Abel Brace is buried in the Catskill Village Cemetery.

name: Betsey Doane Brace
biographical_notes: Betsey Doane Brace was the daughter of John Doane and Eunice Tuttle Doane. Born on October 23, 1795 Betsey was the first of John Doane's fourteen children. She later married Dr. Abel Brace of Catskill, New York. According to family tradition, Betsey attended the Litchfield Female Academy as a young woman. In 1817 she was married to Abel Brace, a Doctor practicing in Catskill, NY, and a nephew of Sarah Pierce and brother of John Pierce Brace. During their marriage Abel and Betsey had several children. Following Abel's death in 1863 Betsey lived with her brother George in Catskill for a time. She passed away in Catskill on July 12, 1881.
citation_of_attendance: [We are currently working to update and confirm citations of attendance.]
additional_notes: Betsey Brace is buried in the Catskill Village Cemetery.
quotes: 'We went from Albany to Catskill a week ago last Wednesday a most dreadful day - the newspapers stated that it was the coldest morning that has been known for these many years, and had I known it was so very cold I should have suffered most amazingly - but as it was we got along very comfortably. We found all our dear friends in Catskill very well - my new sister [Bestey Doane Brace] is a dear sweet creature, I lover her very much - she and my brother [Abel Brace] stay with my Aunt this winter, but they will go to housekeeping the first of May - how I long to have you become acquainted with her and my brother. I know you will love her.'    - Anna Brace Loring to Charles Greely Loring, Litchfield, 23 February 1818 (Private Collection)
materials: Anna Brace Loring letter;Painted fabric and leather 'Old Woman who Lived in a Shoe';Betsey Doane Brace

name: John Doane
biographical_notes: John Doane and his first wife, Eunice, had five children during their marriage. John had nine children with his second wife, Eliza Todd.

name: Lindsley Beach
additional_notes: Lindsley is buried in the Catskill Village Cemetery.

name: Henry M. Brace
biographical_notes: Henry M. Brace, son of Abel Brace and Betsey Doane Brace, was born on May 20, 1828. After graduating from Yale in 1847 he taught school in his hometown for three years, then studied law in an office in New York City, and was admitted to the bar in November of 1851. He continued the active practice of his profession until feeble health cause him to retire. In 1855 he wed Emeline C. Demarest, and the couple had one son. Henry M. Brace died from acute bronchitis, at Catskill, New York, on July 10, 1901.

name: Anna Brace Fitch
additional_notes: Anna Brace's marriage to Ives Fitch took place at her father's home. Witness included the family of Dr. Brace, and friends.     Ives Fitch and Anna Brace Fitch were divorced in 1865.

name: Ives Fitch
additional_notes: The marriage of Ives Fitch and Anna Brace Fitch took place in Catskill at Anna's father's house. Witnesses included Dr. Brace's family, and friends.    Ives Fitch and Anna Brace Fitch were divorced in 1865.

name: Ruth Pierce Croswell
biographical_notes: Ruth Pierce was born in Litchfield, Connecticut February 22, 1765 to John Pierce and his first wife Mary Paterson Pierce. She was Sarah Pierce's older sister. She married Dr. Thomas O'Hara Croswell in 1791 and moved with him to Catskill, New York the following year. They had one adopted daughter. She died January 7, 1862.    Ruth Pierce claimed that she attended George Washington's inauguration on April 30, 1789 by special invitation.

name: Timothy Pierce
biographical_notes: Timothy Pierce was born in Litchfield, Connecticut in 1774. He was the first child from his father, John Pierce's second marriage, with Mary Goodman. He had two siblings, and five half-siblings, one of them being Sarah Pierce. He began a medical practice in South Carolina and died there in 1801.
quotes: 'School consisting of 15 only -- now there are so few I hope the native ladies of Litchfield may stand some chance for a part at least of the attention of Mr. Reeve's students.'  Said to James Pierce regarding the romantic competition between local Litchfield women and Litchfield Female Academy students for Litchfield Law School's male students, 1800.  Emily Noyes Vanderpoel, <U>Chronicles of a Pioneer School from 1792 to 1833: Being the History of Miss Sarah Pierce and her Litchfield School (1903)</U> p.378.     'Does Polly [Mary] Pierce attract the attention of any buck in particular yet? Or is she still obliged to rely on other folks' sweethearts for the amusement of her evenings? Has she nothing to do but look on from 6 o'clock till 10 to see other folks court?'  Said to James Pierce, 1800.

name: Mary Paterson Pierce
biographical_notes: Mary Paterson Pierce was the daughter of Major John Paterson and Ruth Bird Paterson of Wethersfield and Farmington, Connecticut. She married John Pierce in 1750 or 1751. The couple moved to Litchfield, CT in 1753 or 1754. She had one son, following by five daughters, of whom Sarah Pierce was the youngest. Mary Paterson Pierce passed away in 1770.

name: John Pierce Jr.
biographical_notes: John Pierce Jr. was the first and only son of John Pierce and Mary Paterson Pierce. He was born at his maternal grandfather's home in Farmington, Connecticut on December 3, 1752. Soon after his birth, his parents moved to Litchfield, Connecticut. In 1770 John Pierce, Jr.'s mother passed away. His father remarried two years later to Mary Goodman.     In 1775 Pierce joined the Continental Army. By 1776 he had become Assistant Paymaster General, and in 1779 was appointed to the position of Deputy Paymaster General. In 1781 he was named Paymaster General, and ably served his duty until his death in 1788. As Paymaster General John Pierce, Jr. oversaw the paying of more than 93,000 certificates amounting to more than 10 million dollars in deferred pay. Additionally, in 1781 Pierce was entrusted with the task of settling the armies accounts after it was disbanded. By 1787 Congress combined the offices of the Paymaster General and the Commissioner of Army Accounts.    In 1783, Pierce's father passed away and as heir and the oldest of 8 children, he became responsible for his step-mother and younger siblings. Working to achieve financial stability for his family to enable himself to marry Ann Bard in 1786, Pierce brought his sisters Sarah and Nancy (or Anna) to New York City to receive a higher education and to train to become teachers. After John Pierce, Jr.'s sisters returned home to Litchfield, Connecticut, his sister Sarah began the school that would become known as the Litchfield Female Academy. John Pierce Jr. died August 1, 1788. He was thirty five years old and was only married for two years. John's early death left the Pierce family again in financial troubles, but due to John Pierce Jr.'s funding and motivation, the Pierce family found great success in the Litchfield Female Academy, which educated more than three thousand young adults.
private_notes: Information from Chronicles of a New England School and The Papers of Robert Morris, 1781-1784, August-September 1781, footnote #49.
quotes: 'I have flattered myself that my business would have permitted me to visit my friends. and for a moment get away from the thorny and perplexed paths of a public life, but I cannot, and indeed, advantage might be taken of my absence to ruin me ... whim and injustice have induced some and perhaps my own unworthiness, others to write it. I thought that when I did justice to all and followed the strict line of integrity that then 'full sure my greatness would be ripening' - but such characters they oft must meet with disappointment and trouble - if I survive this war with reputation; joyfully in deed I will retire to my friends and domestic peace, and I bid a final adieu to ambition, and to the craft deceit and false friendships of a court.'  - Letter, John Pierce, Jr. to Oliver Wolcott, Jr, 23 August 1782 (Connecticut Historical Society)

name: Thomas O'Hara Croswell
biographical_notes: Thomas O'Hara Croswell was born in 1767. He came to Litchfield, Connecticut when he was young a lived as a 'half servant' in the home of Tapping Reeve. He attended local schools and at the age of 19 he went to live with Dr. Reuben Smith, who lived across the street from the Pierce family, to study apothecary. He later studied with Dr. Daniel Sheldon. He moved to Catskill, NY then returned in 1790 to be Dr. Smith's partner. On July 18, 1791 he married Ruth Pierce, older sister of Sarah Pierce, and the following year they moved to Catskill, NY. They had one adopted daughter. He died January 16, 1844.

name: Levi Lepeon
biographical_notes: Levi Lepeon was a free African American, born in this country to 'native born parents' in 1801. At the age of five he was bound out to Mr. Lyman of Goshen, and afterward to Col. Benjamin Tallmadge of Litchfield and after that Ozias Seymour. About 1843 he moved to New Haven, followed by stays in Bridgeport, CT and Springfield, MA. After 12 years away he returned to Litchfield where he was employed taking care of the offices of several lawyers, including Tapping Reeve and James Gould. He cleaned clothes, blackened boots, made fires and performed other chore. He was familiar to students of the Litchfield Law School. He died February 5, 1867.
additional_notes: Taken from his obituary, 'The Litchfield Enquirer,' February 14, 1867.

name: James Christie Palmer Esten
biographical_notes: James Christie Palmer Esten was a lawyer and judge born November 7, 1805 at St. George, Bermuda, the son of James Christie Esten, chief justice of Bermuda and Ester Palmer.  In 1832 he married Ann Frederica Hutchinson in Exeter, England and had several children.  He died October 24, 1864 in Toronto, Canada.

name: Thomas Whitney Waterman
biographical_notes: Thomas Whitney Waterman was the son of Thomas Glasby Waterman and was born in 1821 in Binghamton, NY.  He entered Yale in 1838, but did not graduate.  He traveled to Europe, studied law and was admitted to the bar in New York in 1848.  Until 1870 he practiced law in New York City and then removed to Binghamton.He edited many law books.

name: William Grimes
biographical_notes: William Grimes was the son of Benjamin Grymes, a wealthy plantation owner in King George County, Virginia and a female slave owned by his neighbor, Dr. Steward. Grimes was owned by ten different masters in Virginia, Maryland and Georgia. In 1814 he escaped by stowing away on a ship bound for New York. From there he made his way to Connecticut, settling in New Haven and later Litchfield, working in both locations as a barber to the local students.IN 1817 he married Clarissa Caesar with whom he had 18 children, 12 surviving to adulthood. He lost all his property and money when he was discovered by his former master and forced to purchase his freedome or return to slavery. During his legal case he was assisted by students from the Litchfield Law School. In 1825 he wrote his autobiography, The Life of William Grimes. It was the first book-length autobiography by a fugitive American slave. William Grimes died in August 1865.

name: James Mark Prevost
biographical_notes: James Mark Prevost was an officer of the British army who married Theodosia Bartow in 1763. He died in service in Jamaica in 1781.

name: Cynthia Trowbridge Dunbar
biographical_notes: Cynthia Trowbridge Dunbar was the wife of Miles Dunbar, a 1809 graduate of Tapping Reeve's Litchfield Law School. On February 12, 1810 the couple were married and resided in Sharon, CT where Miles worked as a lawyer and music teacher. In 1812 they moved to Pine Plains, NY where their first child, Matthew, was born on May 25, 1812.

name: Charles Phelps
secondary_sources: Butler, Henry L. Tales of Our Kinsfolk, Past and Present: The Story of Our Butler Ancestors. Madison: University of Wisconsin, 1919. Google Books. Google, 10 Jan. 2011. Web. 13 Aug. 2013.

name: Theron Rudd Butler
biographical_notes: Moved west to Ohio as a young man, where he married Mary Beach. Worked for many years in the wholesale dry goods business. After Mary's death, married Maria E. Miller (1827-1910) on 1 June 1848.
secondary_sources: Butler, Henry L. Tales of Our Kinsfolk, Past and Present: The Story of Our Butler Ancestors. Madison: University of Wisconsin, 1919. Google Books. Google, 10 Jan. 2011. Web. 13 Aug. 2013.

name: Catharine Butler
biographical_notes: Married Rev. Selden Haynes.
secondary_sources: Butler, Henry L. Tales of Our Kinsfolk, Past and Present: The Story of Our Butler Ancestors. Madison: University of Wisconsin, 1919. Google Books. Google, 10 Jan. 2011. Web. 13 Aug. 2013.

name: Eliza Butler
biographical_notes: Married Hiram Veltman of Brooklyn and had three children: William, Christopher, and Julia.
secondary_sources: Butler, Henry L. Tales of Our Kinsfolk, Past and Present: The Story of Our Butler Ancestors. Madison: University of Wisconsin, 1919. Google Books. Google, 10 Jan. 2011. Web. 13 Aug. 2013.

name: Isaac Butler
secondary_sources: Butler, Henry L. Tales of Our Kinsfolk, Past and Present: The Story of Our Butler Ancestors. Madison: University of Wisconsin, 1919. Google Books. Google, 10 Jan. 2011. Web. 13 Aug. 2013.

name: George Butler
biographical_notes: died in his youth.
secondary_sources: Butler, Henry L. Tales of Our Kinsfolk, Past and Present: The Story of Our Butler Ancestors. Madison: University of Wisconsin, 1919. Google Books. Google, 10 Jan. 2011. Web. 13 Aug. 2013.

name: Frances Ann Devereux Polk
biographical_notes: Frances married her childhood friend Leonidas Polk in 830. Leonidas studied at the Raleigh Academy, UNC Chapel Hill, West Point, and the Virginia Theological Seminary. After he was ordained in Richmond in 1830, the couple settled there. In 1841, when Leonidas was named Bishop of Louisiana, the family relocated to Leighton, Bayou Fourche where they owned a large sugar plantation and taught their slaves Sunday School. They had eight children together. Leonidas found a conflict of morals between his duties as a Planter and Bishop, yet entered the Confederate army at the start of the Civil War and was killed in action at Pine Mountain, GA in June 1864.    With no financial support after her husband's death, Frances resorted to teaching. After teaching English Literature at the Columbia Institute, in New Orleans she later established a school of her own.

name: Catherine Ann Devereux Edmondston
biographical_notes: Kate was the daughter of Thomas Pollock Devereux and his first wife Catherine Ann Johnson; she was known for her Civil War era diary, covering the years 1860-1866, later published as the 'Journal of a Secesh Lady.'     In Feb 1846, Kate married Patrick Muir Edmondston of Charleston, SC at her father's Conneconara plantation. The couple lived in Charleston before permanently moving to NC. Catherine's father gave the newlyweds two plantations adjoining his own, known as Looking Glass and Hascosea as part of a $10,000 marriage settlement. By the 1860 census the couple had a wealthy estate with almost 2000 acres.     Catherine's husband Patrick was active in County affairs, serving as County Justice of the Peace, Vice President of the Scotland Neck Agricultural Society, and organizer of the Scotland Neck Mounted Riflemen. In addition, he was an active member of the Home Guard, organizing defense construction along the Roanoke River. He died in Aug 1871.    In 1872, Kate anonymously published a 40 page pamphlet, 'The Morte d'Arthur; Its Influence on the Spirit and Manners of the Nineteenth century.' With the family estates suffering great recourse from the War, Kate denounced the Freedman's Bureau and 'extolled Confederate Chivalry' throughout. She died three years later in Raleigh, likely of consumption.
secondary_sources: 'Introduction.' Journal of a Secesh Lady: The Diary of Catharine Ann Devereux Edmondston. Ed. Beth G. Crabtree and James W. Patton. 3rd ed. Raleigh: North Carolina Division of Archives and History, 1995. Xi-Xxxvii. Print.
materials: John Devereux Papers, 1712 - 1892;Plantation Sketches;Photograph Of Catherine Ann Devereux Edmondston

name: George Read
admitted_to_bar: Admitted to the Delaware Bar Association in 1785
training_with_other_lawyers: Studied under father George Read Sr.
biographical_notes: George Read, Jr. was born the oldest son to the signer of the Declaration of Independence and U.S. Constitution, George Read Sr. He studied law with his father before serving as a U.S. District Attorney for Delaware from 1789-1836. In 1797, George Read Jr. began construction on a family residence adjacent to his father’s home on the Strand in New Castle, DE, which would be the largest home in Delaware at the time of its completion. The mansion, constructed in the Philadelphian Federal Style, had no expense spared throughout its 14,000 square feet, and was noted for its luxuries and elements of technologically innovative design. The Read family began residence in 1803, and here George lived until his death in 1836.

name: Alanson Abbe
other_education: Phillips Academy, Andover, MA  Yale Department of Medicine, 1821
biographical_notes: Alanson Abbe was educated at Phillips Academy in Andover, MA, and later graduated from the Yale Medical Department in 1821. He took up the study of medicine under Dr. Thompson of Tolland, CT. Alanson was a prominent physician in Litchfield, specializing in the treatment of spinal and orthopedic issues. While living in LItchfield, he used his home on South Street as a hospital for a decade before moving to Boston in 1839 where he continued his practice. He died there in 1864 of complications from a 'brain disease' involving paralysis. His home in Litchfield still stands as a prominent example of Greek Revival architecture in the area.
secondary_sources: Historic Buildings of Connecticut: The Alanson Abbe House Abbe, Cleveland and Nichols, Josephine. Abbe-Abbey Genealogy, in Memory of John Abbe and his Descendants. New Haven: The Tuttle, Morehouse & Taylor Company, 1916.
private_notes: Phillips Academy citation:  Catalogue of the trustees, instructors and students of Phillips Academy, Andover, August, 1817. [Andover, Mass. : Printed by Flagg & Gould, 1817]

name: Theodosia Burr Alston
biographical_notes: Theodosia Burr Alston was the only child of Theodosia Bartow Prevost Burr and Aaron Burr. Aaron and her mother desired for her to receive the best education possible, far past the degree most women of her station were educated at the time period. After her mother's death in 1794, she was her father's closest confidante and devoted daughter, managing his Richmond Hill estate. She married Joseph Alston, the Governor of South Carolina, in 1801. Their son, Aaron Burr Alston, was born in 1802. After her father returned from a period abroad in Europe in 1812, she attempted to sail to NY to meet him and was lost at sea aboard The Patriot with the entire crew in January 1813. Her son Aaron Burr Alston died of a fever just before she left for the voyage. The cause of the ship's loss remains unknown to this day, and her disappearance is featured amongst the legends and folklore of the coast of the Carolinas.
additional_notes: References to Theodosia Burr Alston are made in Robert Frost's 'Kitty Hawk' poem.

name: Abel Catlin
biographical_notes: Abel Catlin served as a surgeon's mate in Colonel Benjamin Hinman's 4th Connecticut Regiment. He was appointed chief surgeon by Governor Trumbull, entered the navy, was taken prisoner and later released.

name: Lydia Harris Birch
additional_notes: Lydia Harris Birch is buried in Woodland Cemetery in Cleveland, OH.

name: Elizabeth Dutton Webber
other_name: Elizabeth Dutton Lakin; Betsey Dutton Lakin; Betsey Dutton Webber
biographical_notes: Elizabeth 'Betsey' Dutton was born in Westford, MA on December 4, 1773. In 1792 Betsey was married to Captain Ebenezer Lakin in Cavendish, VT. After Ebenezer's death in 1808, Betsey was remarried to Christopher Webber of Rutland, VT on December 12, 1809. Around 1810-12 Christopher and Betsey removed to Cavendish and built and lived in what is now the General George F. Davis home in the village of Duttonsville. Betsey Webber passed away in Cavendish on January 19, 1835 at the age of 60.

name: Achsah Wilder Webber
biographical_notes: Achsah Wilder, born January 12, 1791, was the daughter of Jacob and Lydia Sawyer Wilder of Plymouth, VT. Between 1835 and 1848 she was married to Christopher Webber of Cavendish, VT. Achsah died March 17, 1848.

name: Relief Wilder Webber
biographical_notes: Relief Wilder was born February 27, 1793 to Jacob and Lydia Sawyer Wilder of Plymouth, VT. After the death of her sister, Achsah Wilder Webber, on March 17, 1848 she was married to Achsah Widower, Christopher Webber of Cavendish, VT. Relief died in Cavendish, VT on September 14, 1856,

name: Ebenezer Lakin
biographical_notes: General Ebenezer Lakin was born Feburary 3, 1767 to Gabriel and Phoebe Lakin. He was married in Cavendish, VT to Elizabeth Dutton on January 29, 1792. He died on August 28, 1808 in Plymouth, VT.

name: Caroline Anderson Stiles
biographical_notes: Caroline and her husband Eugene West Stiles had one daughter, Eugenia Stiles.
additional_notes: Caroline Anderson Stiles is buried in White Cemetery in Shawsville, Va.

name: Rosabel Bolling Stiles
biographical_notes: Rosabel Bolling Stiles was the second wife of Eugene West Stiles. The couple lived on a farm in Seneca Hollow, VA and had eight children during their marriage.
additional_notes: Rosabel and Eugene West Stiles are buried in Sunset Cemetery in Christansburg, VA.

name: Benjamin Edwards Mayo
biographical_notes: Teacher

name: Caroline Wells
biographical_notes: Died when she was eight years old.

name: Mary Slaughter
biographical_notes: The Daughter of John and Jane Wells, Mary was the oldest of three children. She Married Lieut. W.A. Slaughter and moved to Washington where Lieut. Slaughter was stationed to protected the frontier from Native American attacks. Lieut. Slaughter was killed by an Indian, three years after the families move to Washington. Mary Slaughter moved back home with her parents for five years. She died on January 3, 1862 during the prime of her life.
